title: Home
content: OpenTextTM Service Management is a service management solution driven by analytics. It combines four key application areas: IT Service Management (ITSM) supports organizations to do service management for IT use cases.Extended Service Management (XSM) supports organizations to do service management for non-IT use cases, commonly in departments such as HR, Facilities, or Legal. It also includes Customer Service Management (CSM), which helps organizations efficiently support customers who have purchased their products. The experience and execution of XSM is very similar to IT Service ManagementIT Asset Management (ITAM) helps organizations to manage their hardware and software assets, optimize spend, ensure compliance, and consolidate Asset Management for projects. Cloud Management offers the Design and Deploy (DND) and Cloud Cost Reporting capabilities. title: Get started
content: OpenText Service Management is an analytics-driven service management solution. It combines four key application areas: IT Service Management (ITSM), IT Asset Management (ITAM), Extended Service Management (XSM), and Cloud Management. ITSM and ITAM are available out-of-the-box. You can extend them in a codeless manner. You can find available ITSM and ITAM apps in ITOM Marketplace.XSM works based on out-of-the-box content such as HR workflows. You can extend them in a codeless manner. You can find available XSM apps in ITOM Marketplace.Cloud Management offers the following capabilities: Design and Deploy (DND)Cloud Cost ReportingImage AggregationContent Management OpenText Service Management is offered as a service (SaaS), you can also deploy it on-premises or in the cloud. Additionally, its multi-tenancy support allows you to host and manage environments for multiple customers within a single installation. For more information about the supported deployment platforms, see Install. Open

title: Glossary
content: A Action An action is a software component invoked by the OO run time in order to achieve a certain task. An action can be developed using the Java or Python programming language. Actions are packaged in the form of a .JAR files and can be used as the basis for operations. In addition to the actions developed by OO, an action can be developed at your own site or provided by a third party vendor aiming to extend the capabilities of OO. Agreement An agreement is a document describing a formal understanding between two or more parties. An agreement isn't legally binding unless it forms a contract. AKS Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS), a highly available, secure, and fully managed Kubernetes service. Amazon EKS Amazon EKS is a managed service that makes it easy for you to run Kubernetes on AWS without needing to install and operate your own Kubernetes control plane or worker nodes. Analytic report Reports that reflect historical data for a record type over time. They are calculated according

title: Get started with OMT
content: OMT stands for OPTIC Management Toolkit, the necessary tooling for installing and running containerized ITOM applications on Kubernetes. If you're just getting started with OMT and want to learn what it is, what it can do, and why you might need to use it, see Get started with OMT.

title: Evolving to OpenText Service Management
content: The expectations of both the business and the end-users have around the service desk have changed. As a result of organizations moving towards digitization, and the way in which users engage with technology and services in non-work contexts, there has been a shift in how employees and IT work together. However, this new synergy brings requirements that a classically deployed, stable legacy service management architecture cannot easily meet. As your organization considers a digital transformation strategy that will enable it to operate with greater ease, efficiency, productivity, and overall agility, and to keep users happy and engaged, your IT service management processes must adopt these modern capabilities. We will help you achieve that when transitioning to Service Management. This documentation will focus on the evolution process when coming from the Service Manager, but the approach is general enough that with small modifications it can be used for any existing service management

title: Evolving from Service Manager
content: When evolving an existing Service Manager system, it's highly recommended to follow the overall guidelines and steps from the Implementation Checklist in the Key concepts guide. In addition to the information contained in the checklist, this section highlights additional steps and information that's directly related to a Service Manager implementation. Although these documents are specific to Service Manager, they may also be useful when evolving from other systems as well. This information includes: Differences from Service Manager Collecting Environment Information Core Data and the SMA Evolution Toolkit SMAX/SM Dual Mode

title: EMS REST API
content: Introduction Service Management includes multiple REST APIs that may be used to execute a variety of commands. This document describes using the Postman client to access the EMS REST API. EMS stands for Entity Management System, and is used to access and modify information for most record types in SMA-X, such as incidents, requests, services, and configuration items. Before using the information in this chapter it will be necessary to review the information found in the ‘Configuring Postman’ chapter of this guide. This chapter explains how to install the Postman client as well as how to find the master node and tenant Id for a specific Service Management instance. This chapter will cover: Understanding the data structure of the API Determining the entity type and field names Handling specific field types Locking system - service behavior Special considerations of the EMS API Retrieving information from Service Management Posting information to Service Management Determining entity type

Determining the entity type and field names

title: Enhancing Workflow with Models
content: Introduction When certain sub-types of processes necessitate additional process definition on top of the existing workflow, the Service Management administrator can define specific Model records. These models allow the default workflow to be extended in multiple ways, including: Adding additional fields, called User options Adding business rules Adding specific tasks during multiple workflow phases Setting default values that are set when the model is selected Models are available for the following processes: Change Incident Knowledge (Article models) Release Request (Offerings) The following areas support models, but only for setting supporting information/default fields: Asset Models License Models The administrator can define models in these areas to create a unique flow on top of the existing process workflow. title: Get started with Native SACM
content: Native SACM is a single solution for the entire Service Asset & Configuration Management (SACM) process with instant access to the data and embedded graphical widgets for CI topology representation. Instead of a loosely coupled and single-directional data replication, Native SACM is a natively connected solution that enables bi-directional data federation between Service Management and OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB. Comparison Native SACM is optional. You may have no integration, continue to use the integration with UCMDB based on OPB, use Native SACM, or use a custom integration. Service Management without UCMDB Service Management with UCMDB based on OPB Service Management with Native SACM It's difficult to manually keep models up to date. Scheduled data synchronization to Service Management. Real-time data federation for up-to-date services and inventory. Unidirectional data flow from UCMDB to Service Management. Bi-directional data flow. Limited CI types are supported out o

title: Get started with Cloud Management
content: Cloud Management simplifies the delivery, consumption, and governance of IT services and resources. The codeless and customizable interface, powered with workflow orchestration, service designer, simplified catalog, and a smart service portal, provides for the complete lifecycle management of public and private cloud resources-based IT services. Cloud Management offers the following capabilities: Design and deploy Using Design and Deploy (DND), you can create service designs and offerings, and automate the provisioning and management, of hybrid and multi-cloud resources. The DND capability allows you to automate a wide variety of resource requests with an on-demand selection of parameters and options. From the Main Menu go to Build > Design. For more information, see Design and Deploy. Before enabling and using the Design and Deploy functionality, you should have installed the Operations Orchestration Containerized capability. For more information on how to install Operations Orchestra

title: Get started with Cloud Cost Reporting
content: Cloud Cost Reporting provides enterprises with clear visibility into their cloud spending through interactive, dynamic reports. It helps enterprises monitor costs and make informed decisions to improve return on investment (ROI) and enforce accountability. How Cloud Cost Reporting works Cloud Cost Reporting depends on Operations Platform for data storage and reporting. Cloud Management retrieves billing data and cloud account information from your cloud environments. Operations Platform stores the billing data and provides reporting capabilities to analyze cloud spending. Operations Platform components used by Cloud Cost Reporting Cloud Cost Reporting relies on the following components within Operations Platform to store data and display reports: OPTIC Data Lake - Stores the billing data collected by Cloud Management. This data is stored in Vertica, the analytics database used by OPTIC Data Lake.Operations Cloud - Provides the reporting interface where to create and view reports.Identi

The capability contains the following functional components: OO Central with an Internal OO Remote Action Service (RAS) - These components are available when you install OO Containerized. OO Containerized can be installed on the following platforms: On-premises: Install on physical or virtual machines. See Install OO on-premises. Public cloud: Install on a public cloud–Amazon Web Services (AWS) with EKS, or Microsoft Azure with AKS. See  Install OO on EKS and Install OO on AKS. OO Workflow Designer - You need to install this separately on an on-premises environment using a standalone installer. External RAS - You need to install this separately on an on-premises environment using a standalone installer. title: Get started with Aviator
content: Aviator is a virtual assistant built upon a private Large Language Model (LLM). It seamlessly integrates advanced language models to ease natural and effective conversations, while adhering to stringent privacy and data security requirements essential for businesses, government agencies, and organizations. Aviator excels at facilitating domain-specific conversations by leveraging real-time enterprise data and documents. With adaptive chunking, Aviator processes only the relevant information. This makes it a valuable tool for IT, HR, sales, and support desk teams, streamlining processes and providing highly relevant virtual agent services. You can use Aviator in Service Portal, Agent Interface, Mobile app, and Microsoft Teams bot. Aviator in Service Portal Aviator in Service Portal offers these features: Knowledge base integration: Enables Q&A interactions based on your knowledge base. Reference articles and news: Provides support for referencing articles, news, offerings, and remote ar

title: Get started with Inbox
content: Inbox provides the agent users with a comprehensive single-page view of all the functionalities related to them. They can quickly access the tasks owned by them, assigned to them, and owned by the groups they belong to. The tasks may span across several record types that end users are associated with such as Service Request Management, Incident Management, Problem Management, Change Management, and Task Management. Inbox makes it easy to track, prioritize, and manage the tasks from the same page. You can enable or disable the consolidated inbox in the Application Settings. For more information, see Enable inbox. Inbox provides out-of-the-box fields and mapping for Service Request, Incident, Problem, Change and Task record types. For more information, see Configure Inbox. To know how to manage the Inbox, see Use inbox.

title: Ensure compliance of resources provisioned outside Cloud Management
content: Tags can help you manage, identify, organize, search for, and filter resources. With tagged resources, admin users and management personnel can: Identify the resources provisioned by each team/team member. Teams that are part of a centralized cost center can share a resource. By having proper tags in place, it's easier to break up the incurred cost and charge back the teams as appropriate. Identify the hierarchical consumption of cloud resources in a team. This use case describes how to ensure your cloud resources provisioned outside OpenText Cloud Management have proper tags assigned. This use case involves the following personas. Persona Role Responsibilities Stephen Compliance Administrator or Engineer Create a policy and ensure that it is run as per schedule Set up the dashboard report and the report that needs to be sent to account owner or group Derek Application Engineer Assign the appropriate tags in the expected format to provisioned resources and make them compliant. title: Hardware requirements for option 3: SMA + DND + OO + CMP FinOps
content: If you plan to use deployment option 3 (SMA + DND + OO + CMP FinOps), plan your hardware resources as follows. In this release, support for AlloyDB Omni is under controlled availability. Please contact our product management team before you begin the implementation in your production environment. To set up OO with a common database, you can choose to connect OO to the same database instance as the rest of the suite components. title: Hardware requirements for other options
content: If none of the typical deployment options described previously meets your needs, use the following guidelines. How to calculate hardware resources You can determine your hardware requirements as follows: Use the deployment size definitions for the SMA capability to determine the SMA deployment size and required hardware resources (see Hardware requirements for option 1). Use this hardware resource requirement as a basis.Use the deployment size definitions for each of the other desired capabilities to determine their deployment size and additional hardware resources required.Calculate the total hardware resources required by adding up the requirements for all capabilities, and add resources as needed: worker nodes, CPU, RAM, and disk storage. Note that when calculating how many worker nodes are needed, keep in mind that all worker nodes must have the same hardware specification provided here because Kubernetes schedules pods across all of the worker nodes. For more information about NFS

title: High Availability PostgreSQL with Patroni
content: Patroni is a tool for deploying PostgreSQL servers in high-availability mode. Practice guidance of any third-party products (for example, PostgreSQL HA) provided here is for reference purposes only with an intention to help customers. However, customers will remain responsible for ensuring that the end-to-end solution works with the underlying infrastructure, hardware/software dependencies, and more. OpenText will extend its responsibility and support for OpenText products only per contractual agreements as applicable. Patroni architecture The following diagram illustrates the architecture of a highly available PostgreSQL cluster using Patroni and HAProxy. You can deploy a hardware load balancer to replace HAProxy and Keepalived in the following diagram. In our lab environment, we've validated the configurations and deployments with an F5 load balancer. Patroni is a cluster manager that can customize and automate the deployment and maintenance of PostgreSQL HA (High Availability) clust

title: Generate vault secrets
content: Generate vault secrets for the UD/UCMDB charts On the control plane node, perform the following tasks to generate vault secrets for the UD/UCMDB charts: Run the following command: $CDF_HOME/scripts/gen_secrets.sh -n <UD/UCMDB NAMESPACE> -c <UD/UCMDB CHART FILE> -o <SECRETS YAML FILE> Where: <UD/UCMDB NAMESPACE> is the unique namespace of the UD/UCMDB deployment. Use the namespace that you specified in the "Create a new deployment for UD/UCMDB" topic. <UD/UCMDB CHART FILE> is the tar file containing the UD/UCMDB installation charts (ucmdb-1.xx.x-xxx+2x.x.x.tgz) <SECRETS YAML FILE> is the YAML file that stores the UD/UCMDB secrets. Specify the file name (for example, cms-secrets.yaml), and then the script will generate this YAML file after you run the script. You will need to use this file when you run the command to install UD/UCMDB later. For example: /opt/cdf/scripts/gen_secrets.sh -n ucmdb-prod -c UCMDB_Helm_Chart-2x.x/ucmdb-helm-charts/charts/ucmdb-1.xx.x-xxx+2x.x.x.tgz -o cms-secre
headings: Generate vault secrets for the UD/UCMDB charts
Update UD/UCMDB secret with suite IdM secrets

title: Get connection details for connecting to the Service Management IdM
content: This topic contains instructions to get the connection details to connect with the Service Management IdM. Use this information during the preparation of the sensitive data required by OO installation. Obtain the password for the IdM transport user Run the following commands to obtain the password from Service Management's vault for the user idmTransportUser. Get the Service Management namespace: SMAX_NS=$(echo `kubectl get ns | grep itsma | awk '{print $1}'`) && echo $SMAX_NS Get the IdM's pod name: SMAX_IDM_POD=$(echo `kubectl get pods -n $SMAX_NS | grep -m1 idm- | head -1 | awk '{print $1}'`) && echo $SMAX_IDM_POD Get the password for the Service Management IdM user idmTransportUser: TRANSPORT_PASS=$(kubectl exec -it $SMAX_IDM_POD -n $SMAX_NS -c idm -- bash -c "/bin/get_secret idm_transport_admin_password_secret_key" | awk -F= '{print$2}') && echo $TRANSPORT_PASS
headings: Obtain the password for the IdM transport user
titleLower: get connection details for connecting to the service management idm

title: Generate sensitive data for OO Containerized
content: The outcome of this step is the creation of a Kubernetes secret named oo-secret, that holds the required sensitive data OO needs to be installed: the passwords of the database users created during the preparation steps and the suite IDM integration passwords. The name of this Kubernetes secret is by default referenced in the OO values.yaml file (at the Helm parameter global.initSecrets), and at the time of OO installation, its data is automatically consumed by the deployed OO pods. Use the gen_secrets.sh tool from OMT to prepare the sensitive data. Run the following command on the control plane node: $CDF_HOME/scripts/gen_secrets.sh -n <OO namespace> -c <OO chart file> Where: <OO namespace> is the unique namespace of the OO deployment. Use the namespace you specified in the Create a new deployment for OO page. <OO chart file> is the absolute path of the OO chart file. For example: $CDF_HOME/scripts/gen_secrets.sh -n oo-prod -c oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x/oo-helm-charts/charts/oo-1.x.x+

title: EKS deployment FAQs
content: This topic answers certain most frequently asked questions about deploying the suite on AWS with EKS. GeneralThe following are general questions that apply to all supported cloud platforms. Can I use machine types other than those specified in the sizing guide? No. One VM with 8vCPU can have better performance than 2 VMs with 4vCPU in some scenarios. VMs have their own limitations, so you can't improve system performance simply by adding more VMs. Additionally, all our sizing recommendations, tuning and tests are based on certain requirements for each node. You can't guarantee the performance if using VMs that don't meet the requirements for a node. Can I share storage between development and test environments? Technically, you can. However, we don't recommend it. This is because all our sizing recommendations, tuning and tests are based on an assumption that each environment uses their dedicated storage. Sharing the same storage between two environments may cause the environments to i

title: Get connection details for connecting to the Service Management IdM
content: This topic contains instructions on how to integrate OO with the Service Management IdM. You'll use the information obtained from Generate sensitive data for OO in the following steps. Obtain the password for the IdM transport user Run the following commands on the bastion node to obtain the password from the Service Management's vault for the user idmTransportUser. You'll need to use this user for the integration between OO and IdM. Get the Service Management namespace: SMAX_NS=$(echo `kubectl get ns | grep itsma | awk '{print $1}'`) && echo $SMAX_NS Get the IdM pod name: SMAX_IDM_POD=$(echo `kubectl get pods -n $SMAX_NS | grep -m1 idm- | head -1 | awk '{print $1}'`) && echo $SMAX_IDM_POD Get the password for the IdM user idmTransportUser: TRANSPORT_PASS=$(kubectl exec -it $SMAX_IDM_POD -n $SMAX_NS -c idm -- bash -c "/bin/get_secret idm_transport_admin_password_secret_key" | awk -F= '{print$2}') && echo $TRANSPORT_PASS

contentLower: this topic answers the most frequently asked questions about deploying the suite in a gcp environment.generalthe following are general questions that apply to all supported cloud platforms. can i use machine types other than those specified in the sizing guide? no. one vm with 8vcpu can have better performance than 2 vms with 4vcpu in some scenarios. vms have their own limitations, so you can't improve system performance simply by adding more vms. additionally, all our sizing recommendations, tuning and tests are based on certain requirements for each node. you can't guarantee the performance if using vms that don't meet the requirements for a node. can i share storage between development and test environments? technically, you can. however, we don't recommend it. this is because all our sizing recommendations, tuning and tests are based on an assumption that each environment uses their dedicated storage. sharing the same storage between two environments may cause the environments to i

title: Generate vault secrets (GCP)
content: Generate vault secrets for the UD/UCMDB charts Perform the following tasks to generate vault secrets for the UD/UCMDB charts: On the bastion node, navigate to the OMT installation directory: cd OMT_External_K8s_2x.x-xxx/scripts/ Run the following command to generate vault secrets: ./gen_secrets.sh -n <UD/UCMDB NAMESPACE> -c <UD/UCMDB CHART FILE> -o <SECRETS YAML FILE> Where: <UD/UCMDB NAMESPACE> is the unique namespace of the UD/UCMDB deployment. Use the namespace that you specified in the "Create a new deployment for UD/UCMDB" topic. <UD/UCMDB CHART FILE> is the tar file containing the UD/UCMDB installation charts. <SECRETS YAML FILE> is the YAML file that stores the UD/UCMDB secrets. Specify the file name (for example, uducmdb-secrets.yaml), and then the script will generate this YAML file after you run the script. You will need to use this file when you run the command to install UD/UCMDB later. For example: ./gen_secrets.sh -n ucmdb-prod -c UCMDB_Helm_Chart-2x.x/ucmdb-helm-charts/c
headings: Generate vault secrets for the UD/UCMDB charts
contentLower: generate vault secrets for the ud/ucmdb charts perform the following tasks to generate vault secrets for the ud/ucmdb charts: on the bastion node, navigate to the omt installation directory: cd omt_external_k8s_2x.x-xxx/scripts/ run the following command to generate vault secrets: ./gen_secrets.sh -n <ud/ucmdb namespace> -c <ud/ucmdb chart file> -o <secrets yaml file> where: <ud/ucmdb namespace> is the unique namespace of the ud/ucmdb deployment. use the namespace that you specified in the "create a new deployment for ud/ucmdb" topic. <ud/ucmdb chart file> is the tar file containing the ud/ucmdb installation charts. <secrets yaml file> is the yaml file that stores the ud/ucmdb secrets. specify the file name (for example, uducmdb-secrets.yaml), and then the script will generate this yaml file after you run the script. you will need to use this file when you run the command to install ud/ucmdb later. for example: ./gen_secrets.sh -n ucmdb-prod -c ucmdb_helm_chart-2x.x/ucmdb-helm-charts/c

title: Generate vault secrets (OpenShift)
content: Generate vault secrets for the UD/UCMDB charts Perform the following tasks to generate vault secrets for the UD/UCMDB charts: On the bastion node, run the following command: $CDF_HOME/scripts/gen_secrets.sh -n <UD/UCMDB NAMESPACE> -c <UD/UCMDB CHART FILE> -o <SECRETS YAML FILE> Where: <UD/UCMDB NAMESPACE> is the unique namespace of the UD/UCMDB deployment. Use the name that you specified when creating the project for UD/UCMDB deployment in OpenShift. <UD/UCMDB CHART FILE> is the tar file containing the UD/UCMDB installation charts (ucmdb-1.x.x+2x.x.x-xxx.tgz) <SECRETS YAML FILE> is the YAML file that stores the UD/UCMDB secrets. Specify the file name (for example, cms-secrets.yaml), and then the script will generate this YAML file after you run the script. You will need to use this file when you run the command to install UD/UCMDB later. For example: /opt/cdf/scripts/gen_secrets.sh -n ucmdb-prod -c UCMDB_Helm_Chart-2x.x/ucmdb-helm-charts/charts/ucmdb-1.xx.x-xxx+2x.x.x.tgz -o cms-secret

title: Generate sensitive data for OO on OpenShift
content: The outcome of this step is the creation of a Kubernetes secret named oo-secret, which holds the required sensitive data that OO needs at install time. The name of this Kubernetes secret is by default referenced in the OO values.yaml (at Helm parameter global.initSecrets). At OO install time, its data is automatically consumed by the deployed OO pods. Use the gen_secrets.sh script from OPTIC Management Toolkit (OMT) to prepare the sensitive data. Run the following command on the bastion node: $CDF_HOME/scripts/gen_secrets.sh -n <OO NAMESPACE> -c <OO CHART FILE> Where: $CDF_HOME is the installation directory of OMT. <OO NAMESPACE> = the unique namespace of the OO deployment. <OO CHART FILE> = the absolute path of the OO chart file For example: $CDF_HOME/scripts/gen_secrets.sh -n oo -c oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x/oo-helm-charts/charts/oo-1.x.x+26.x.x.tgz The Vault secret utility prompts you for the following passwords. Vault Secrets Key Required? Description idm_admin_admin_password Yes

title: Enable TLS on PostgreSQL
content: You can skip this topic if: you are using CA-signed certificatesyou are using self-signed CA certificatesyou have an embedded PostgreSQL setupyou are already familiar with configuring TLS on a PostgreSQL serveryou do not require TLS for your deployment In these cases, the steps outlined in this page may not be necessary. Create certificate using cdfcert tool for PostgreSQL Run the following command to create the certificate: cdfcert cert create postgres -S mypostgres.host1.net -d . This creates the following files: cdf_ca.crt postgres.crt postgres.key If you create the certificate using the cdfcert tool on the control plane node, you must copy them onto the PostgreSQL database server for updating the postgresql.conf file. For the complete documentation on how to configure PostgreSQL with TLS, see Secure TCP/IP Connections with SSL in the PostgreSQL documentation. For PostgreSQL 13, see https://www.postgresql.org/docs/13/ssl-tcp.html. The instructions for Creating Certificates of the Po

title: Enable TLS in Oracle
content: This topic provides information on enabling TLS in Oracle database on a Linux environment. You may skip this topic, if you are using CA signed certificates, self signed CA certificates, if you are aware of configuring TLS on Oracle server, or if you do not require TLS. If the database is present on any other environment, for example, Windows, you must work with your Database Administrator (DBA) to complete the required setup and configurations. For Configuring SSL/TLS on ORACLE RAC you must refer to Oracle’s documentation. TLS configuration You can follow one of the following methods to create an auto_login wallet to configure TLS for an Oracle database on a Linux host. Example to create certificate using cdfcert tool to configure TLS On the control plane node, run the cdfcert tool for Oracle to generate cdf_ca.crt, oracle_server.key, and oracle_server.crt: cdfcert cert create oracle_server -S <Oracle hostname> -d . Copy the newly created certificates to the Oracle database server. Run

title: Enable OPTIC Data Lake Message Bus data distribution
content: Skip this topic if you are installing on-premises or on-cloud in a single zone. This topic gives steps to enable OPTIC Data Lake Message Bus data distribution across multiple zones for embedded or external Kubernetes deployment where the worker nodes are in different zones. OPTIC Data Lake Message Bus stores the data temporarily before it's loaded to the Vertica database. The volumes provisioned for the OPTIC Data Lake Message Bus store this data. The BookKeeper (Bookies) stores the messages forwarded to the OPTIC Data Lake Message Bus. The message gets written to two Bookies which helps to avoid data loss when a Bookie or node crashes in the deployment. It's necessary to set a placement policy to ensure the data replicas are placed on Bookies in different zones. In an AWS deployment, the data replicas are distributed across different zones by default. This helps to avoid data loss when there is a zone failure. In an embedded Kubernetes deployment, the data distributions are across dif

title: Enable DND
content: This topic describes how to enable the Design and Deploy (DND) capability for an existing tenant. You need to assign a Cloud Management license to the tenant to access the Design and Deploy functionality. For step-by-step instructions on how to enable DND for a tenant and an example use case of DND aggregated offerings, see Cloud Management use case - Design and Deploy. Prerequisites Before you proceed, meet the following prerequisites. Make sure the DND capability has been installed in the suite. To see if DND is installed, run the kubectl get pods --all-namespaces | grep dnd command to see if all the DND pods are running and run the kubectl get job --all-namespaces | grep dnd command to make sure all DND job resources have a Complete status. If DND isn't yet installed, you need to add the DND capability to your existing installation. Note that in an on-premises environment, you must modify the pg_hba.conf file of the external PostgreSQL database as required. Make sure the Operations

title: Enable SAM
content: Prerequisites To access the new SAM capability, you need to: Assign an Asset Management license to your tenant Enable Native SACM for your tenant Architecture overview The following architecture diagrams describe how SAM can be deployed. You can choose either the multi-deployment mode or the classic deployment mode. Multi-deployment: Deploy Service Management and Universal Discovery and CMDB (UD/UCMDB) on the same Kubernetes cluster, in an on-premises, AKS, EKS, or OpenShift environment. Classic deployment: Install classic UCMDB Server and classic UCMDB Gateway. Support matrix To enable SAM, install UCMDB Server of versions described in Service Management integration with Universal Discovery and CMDB. Deployment procedure To deploy the SAM capability, follow these steps: Install UD/UCMDB for SAM Enable the SAM capability (Optional) Change the SAM deployment size after installation For demo or testing purposes, you can deploy SAM's sample data in the environment where you plan to run SA

title: Enable the SAM capability
content: After you install the suite, you can add the SAM capability for a tenant. Note that: You can't disable SAM after you enable it for a tenant. If the original Software Asset Management module in Service Management is already in use before you enable the new SAM capability, that data won't be migrated to the new SAM solution after you enable it. Prerequisites Before deploying the new SAM capability in the suite, make sure you have installed it in the suite. To see if SAM is installed, run the kubectl get pods --all-namespaces | grep sam command. Make sure the sam-deploy-controller pod is in the Completed state. If SAM isn't installed, you can add the SAM capability to your existing installation. Or, you can install a new suite with the SAM capability enabled in the values.yaml file. title: Enable Native SACM
content: Native SACM is a single solution for the entire Service Asset & Configuration Management (SACM) process with instant access to the data and embedded graphical widgets for CI topology representation. Native SACM enables bidirectional data federation between SMA and CMS by establishing a bridge called UCMDB Gateway. Notes: UCMDB and UCMDB Gateway can be external (classic mode) or containerized (multiple deployment mode). To use Native SACM, you are recommended to deploy SMA in an on-premises, AWS (EKS), Azure (AKS), or Red Hat OpenShift environment. Google Cloud Platform (GCP) is also supported starting from this release. Native SACM architecture The following figures show the currently supported architecture of Native SACM. Classic UD/UCMDB Containerized UD/UCMDB Related topics Native SACM Integrate with UCMDB Configure Native SACM with Studio

title: Enable Native SACM in Service Management
content: Sample data Sample data is for demo or testing purposes. To deploy sample data for an environment planned to run in the Native SACM mode, we recommend that you follow these steps: Deploy a new trial tenant in Suite Administration but DO NOT activate Native SACM yet. Once the tenant is active, deploy the Service Management sample data. Once the sample data is deployed, go back to the Suite Administration and activate Native SACM by following the steps in the relevant sections of this topic. During the activation of Native SACM, the sample data and service models are migrated to UCMDB. If you activate Native SACM prior to deploying the sample data, the data will not be completely migrated to UCMDB. Especially, the relationships between CIs will be missing. Therefore, if you intend to use the sample data, make sure to follow the steps above. Additional data can be directly loaded into UCMDB using the Package Manager or using the JMX console. title: Enable enhanced CI aging
content: After you enabled Native SACM, it is strongly recommended that you enable the enhanced CI aging feature. With Native SACM enabled, the enhanced CI aging feature enables you to manage the lifecycle of CIs. If Universal Discovery hasn't discovered a CI for a predefined period of time, the system sets its discovery state to Purgeable in UD/UCMDB rather than auto-purges it in the traditional way. You can then retire the purgeable CI either manually or automatically via workflows. For example, you can configure the CI workflow in the agent interface so CIs can be retired and moved to the End of Life metaphase automatically. Likewise, if a CI is provisioned by a Service Design through the DND integration, the CI will be created in UCMDB and then synchronized to Service Management. At this point, the provision state field is set to Provisioned, which indicates its active connection with DND. Later when it enters the end of its lifecycle, the provision state will be set to Purgeable. How to en

title: Enable Audit
content: After you have installed the audit service, you need to connect your system to the Audit service. Prerequisite You must have already installed the audit service. Currently, you can install the Audit service in an on-premises environment or on AWS with EKS. See (Optional) Install the Audit service on-premises and Install the Audit service on AWS (EKS). Prepare an audit integration user In the IdM Admin Portal, you need to prepare an audit integration user so that the system can use it to create audit data. The tenant that the integration user belongs to is called the audit integration tenant. Use the sysbo tenant as the integration tenant. You will need to specify this user and the tenant later when creating an audit client configuration file (audit-client-cfg.properties). The user must be of the System type and have the CREATE_AUDIT permission to create audit data. To prepare this user, follow these steps: Log in to the IdM Admin Portal as suite-admin. From the organization list, open

title: Enable Audit collector
content: Services that are integrated with the Audit service store the audits on the NFS file system when the audit service isn't reachable. Audit collector is a microservice that collects the audits from the NFS file system and passes them to the Audit service via REST. This section describes the steps to install the Audit collector. Prerequisite You must have already installed the audit service.  For more information, see (Optional) Install the Audit service on-premises and Install the Audit service on AWS (EKS).You must have completed the Enable Audit procedure. Configure values.yaml for Audit collector Follow the steps to configure values.yaml file Export the Audit service engine certificate To enable the audit collector to connect to the Audit service, you need to import the Audit service engine certificate. It's highly recommended that you get the correct Root CA certificate from the engineer who creates and administers the Audit service deployment. If this isn't possible, you can export

title: How to uninstall suite Kubernetes configurations and databases
content: The following instructions apply to a helm-based suite deployment on either the embedded Kubernetes or a managed Kubernetes. Uninstall Kubernetes configurations Uninstall the Kubernetes configurations for the suite as follows. We recommend that you uninstall the suite through CLI. If you want to uninstall it through the AppHub application, you must follow step 3 to step 6 below to clean up all PVCs. Log on to a control plane node or the bastion node. Run the following command to uninstall the ESM chart. ns=<NAMESPACE> helm uninstall $(helm list -n $ns |grep -v NAME|awk '{print $1}'|tail -1) -n $ns Where <NAMESPACE> is the unique namespace of the suite deployment. Run the following command to change the status of your persistent volumes (PVs) from Release to Available. Skip this step if you are using dynamic PVs. kubectl patch pv $(kubectl get pv | grep -v NAME |  grep $ns | cut -f1 -d " ") -p '{"spec":{"claimRef":{"resourceVersion":null, "uid":null}}}' Run the following command to conf

title: How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Windows
content: How to install and manage agents To install the On-Premises Bridge agent, you must have the following permissions: Modify, read, write, and execute permissions in the On-Premises Bridge installation folder Permission to create the OpbAgent Windows service, and run services.msc Permission to run tasklist and taskkill commands Create an integration user The OPB agent needs an integration user to connect to Service Management. You'll need to specify this integration user later when installing the OPB agent. The On-Premises Bridge agent must use a dedicated integration user of the DB authentication type, and it can't use a federated user. Don't use an account user with the OPB Remote Agent role for the OPB agent, because the system doesn't allow any users with the OPB Remote Agent role to access either the agent interface or the Service Portal. See also OPB Agent security additional information. Suite Admin can create an integration user with the following steps. Create a user in Suite Adm

title: Enable TLS 1.3 for OPB
content: On-Premises Bridge (OPB) Agent includes support for TLS 1.3. This support is automatically enabled for newly installed OPB Agent, however for OPB Agent upgraded from an earlier version, you need to manually enable TLS 1.3 support if you haven't already done so. The supported cipher suites for TLS 1.3 are TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 and TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384. Enable TLS 1.3 support Use the information below to manually enable TLS 1.3. Go to On-Premise Bridge Agent\product\conf and modify the wrapper-custom.conf file as below: Enable wrapper.java.additional.201 and add "-Djdk.tls.client.protocols=TLSv1.3,TLSv1.2" as executors parameters. Add TLSv1.3 in wrapper.java.additional.303 Add the supported cipher suites in wrapper.java.additional.304 Example : wrapper.java.additional.201=-Dopb.all.executors.params="-Djdk.tls.client.protocols=TLSv1.3,TLSv1.2" wrapper.java.additional.303=-Dtls.protocols=TLSv1.3,TLSv1.2 wrapper.java.additional.304=-Dtls.ciphers=TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA

title: External systems
content: Service Management provides a case exchange framework to exchange data between Service Management and other products. The case exchange framework enables you to define an external system with which information will be exchanged. The following integrations are supported: Service Manager (SM). The SM integration uses the Active/Passive case exchange protocol. In this protocol, all actions are initiated in the external system and no configuration of REST operations is required in Service Management. The On-Premises Bridge isn't involved in the integration; only the Case exchange API is required. For more information, see External systems - Service Manager integration. Operations Manager i (OMi). The OMi integration uses the Active/Active case exchange protocol. In this protocol, actions are initiated from both sides and REST operations are configured in Service Management. The On-Premises Bridge is used in the integration and REST server functionality is required on the external system. F

title: External configurations
content: External configurations are pre-defined content which can be used to simplify the integration with Operations Manager i (OMi). They define how Service Management communicates with the external system. You can apply an external configuration to more than one external system, but each external system can have no more than one external configuration. An external system doesn't require an external configuration. To add an external configuration From the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Integration > External configurations. Click  New to open the New External configuration dialog box. Enter a Name for the external configuration. Click OK. In the Details area, select Enabled for the required operations. For each operation enabled, click the parameter links and select or enter the required parameters. title: Expression language
content: The Expression Language is a language that enables you to construct expressions that you can enter in different parts of the Integration Studio user interface. Tip: You can use the Expression execution details field in the integration execution history details page (accessed from the Endpoint page) to view the actual expression evaluation result. The expressions can be of the following types: A logical expression (&&, ||, ==, !=) A mathematical expression (+, -, /, *) A conditional expression (if-else) An object property (Objects) A function call (DSL functions) You can define complex expressions by combining these types of expressions. Every value which is not a Boolean, number or string is an expression. Note The Integration Studio configuration UI supports the Unicode character set. Supported data types The expressions return a value of a specific data type. The following data types are supported. Data type Example Boolean true, false String 'hello': Returns hello 'he\'l\'lo': Retur

title: Export and import integrations
content: As a best practice, create, configure, and test integrations in the development tenant before you deploy them in the production tenant. You can use the Integration Studio's import/export functionality to migrate integration configuration from the development tenant to the production tenant. First export integrations configured in a tenant to a package (.pkg) file, and then import the export file to another tenant. Export integrations From the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.Click in the left pane, and then click Export.In the Export configuration dialog, select the integrations and scenarios you want to export.Click OK. The export file (.pkb file) that contains the selected integrations and scenarios is automatically downloaded to your browser's download folder. For the export file to be imported to another system, its size must be less than the Max Dev2Prod package file size configured on the tenant's Application settings form in Suite A

title: How-Tos
content: Refer to the following examples when configuring a scenario for your integrations. How to use parse responses and set the output parameters Each task executes a request against either the current or the target system. Each request has a response. The system captures the response details in the following parameters: response.statusCode: contains the raw HTTP response code of the request.response.data: contains the response body. To parse the payload received and captured in the response.data parameter, you can use thejson_parser function. Consider the following sample payload from a GET request: { "entities": [ { "entity_type": "Request", "properties": { "Status": "RequestStatusReady", "LastUpdateTime": 1630462073654, "Id": "12644", "DisplayLabel": "Connection to exchange server is broken." }, "related_properties": {} } ], "meta": { "completion_status": "OK", "total_count": 0, "errorDetailsList": [], "errorDetailsMetaList": [], "query_time": 1636984213234856 } } To extract the values of

title: How to communicate with classic UCMDB using HTTPS
content: If you want to communicate with UCMDB using the HTTPS protocol, you must complete all of the following steps: Enable SSL on the UCMDB server machine. For more information, see the Universal CMDB Hardening Guide. Enable the UCMDB probe to connect to the server using SSL. To do this, you must add a certificate to the probe’s certificate trust store. Create the certificate file. From <UCMDB-Installation-Folder>\bin\jre\bin, run the following command: keytool -exportcert -file <Certificate-File-Name> -alias "hpcert" -keystore C:\UCMDB\UCMDBServer\conf\security\server.keystore Add the certificate from the certificate file to the probe’s certificate trust store: keytool -importcert -file <Certificate-File-Name> -alias "new alias" -keystore <Probe-Installation-Folder>\conf\security\ProbeTrustStore.jks Note The default password of the probe’s trust store is logomania. title: How to set up automatic synchronization with UCMDB through OPB
content: In automatic synchronization mode, you need to create an endpoint in Service Management and start the synchronization process, and then the agent pulls data from UCMDB to Service Management automatically. In this mode, you have little control of the synchronization process and schedule. After the endpoint is created, click Sync Now. An integration point named ucmdb_<TENANT ID> is automatically created in UCMDB. The latest data in the staging area is synchronized to Service Management. The data is pushed to the staging area by a push job which runs according to the scheduler in UCMDB, the default for which is set at every hour. In UCMDB, the push adapter that's deployed has a name of <Tenant ID>_SACMPushAdapter and the integration point that's created has a name of <Endpoint name>_<Tenant ID>. For subsequent, on-demand, synchronizations: To get the latest changed UCMDB data,  run a delta synchronization job in UCMDB to push the changed data to the staging area, and then click Sync Now t

title: How to set up custom synchronization with UCMDB through OPB
content: In custom synchronization mode, you need to manually create an endpoint, download a UCMDB push adapter package and upload it to UCMDB, set up and customize the integration point, and pull data from UCMDB to Service Management. In this mode, you can customize TQLs, mappings, and synchronization jobs as needed. You can also customize your own synchronization schedules. Note If you have customized content, don't run the automatic synchronization, which will overwrite your customized content. When a new version of the custom mode adapter is published, you must manually merge the updated content of the new adapter with your customized content and then run the custom synchronization only. The following steps describe how to set up custom synchronization with UCMDB. Step 1: Set up Service Management for integration with UCMDB For details, see Integrate with external UCMDB. Step 2: Deploy the UCMDB push adapter in UCMDB Each SMAX tenant has a unique UCMDB push adapter, which you must download

title: Enable indexing for existing tenants
content: When you see slow database query performance on the Audit page load, please follow the below steps to introduce the indexes for a specific tenant. To enable indexing in the audit database for existing tenants, you can run queries. Open the query tool for the required schema under the audit table and run the following queries for each column. Run these queries only if the existing tenant has data. The indexing in a fresh tenant or an existing tenant that doesn't have data is done through the code: CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS AUDIT_ACTION ON "<schema>".audit (action); CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS AUDIT_TIME ON "<schema>".audit (audit_time); CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS AUDIT_EVENT_CATEGORY "<schema>".audit (event_category); CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS AUDIT_RESULT ON "<schema>".audit (result); <schema>: The schema for which you want to enable indexing. For example: CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS AUDIT_ACTION ON "SYSBO".audit audit (action); CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS AUDIT_TIME ON "SYSBO".audit (a

title: FIPS mode
content: FIPS (Federal Information Processing Standards) are a set of standards that describe document processing, encryption algorithms, and other information technology standards for use within U.S. non-military government agencies and by U.S. government contractors and vendors who work with the agencies. FIPS is also considered a good standard for all companies that seek a high security standard. FIPS 140-2, “Security Requirements for Cryptographic Modules,” was issued by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) in May 2001. The standard specifies the security requirements for cryptographic modules utilized within a security system that protects sensitive or valuable data. This guide provides guidelines for installing and running OpenText Service Management in FIPS mode. It is strongly recommended that you follow the guidelines strictly to avoid any unforeseen risk that may be introduced by the FIPS solution. In this release, FIPS mode support is under controlled availa

title: Enable a firewall in the suite environment
content: Your SMA production environment is normally behind a corporate firewall as required by your security policy; however, to install and run OMT and SMA, certain ports must be open in the firewall. This document provides detailed instructions on how to open the required ports on all nodes before you start the OMT installation. Note When a firewall is enabled before OMT deployment, OMT will open firewall ports 3000, 5000, 5443 automatically during the deployment. Because these three ports are exposed with the hostPort mode in the Kubernetes cluster, Docker will add the iptable rules to open these ports automatically. You can't block these firewall ports with firewall-cmd anymore. However, if you enable a firewall after OMT is deployed, you have to open all the firewall ports listed below. If you installed the suite with your firewall disabled and want to enable the firewall after installation, follow the instructions in Enable a firewall after installation. Security recommendations We recom

Enable masquerade setting when a firewall is enabled
Enable vrrp protocol for Keepalived in a multiple-control plane node deployment when a firewall is enabled

Step 1: Enable firewalld on each control plane node, worker node, or NFS server
Step 2: Block all inbound connections on each control plane node, worker node, or NFS server
Step 3: Enable k8s networking on each control plane node or worker
Step 4: Open the internal ports on each control plane node or worker node
Step 5: Open the remaining ports on each control plane node, worker node, or NFS server
Step 6: Open the required ports on the PostgreSQL database server and email server

title: Enable log rotation
content: Follow the steps below to implement log rotation so that logs won't use up all storage on the node. Patch itom-ingress-controller-conf to enable log rotation with desired rotation size and round number. Below is an example. namespace=`kubectl get namespace | grep itsma | cut -f1 -d " "` kubectl patch cm itom-ingress-controller-conf -n ${namespace} -p '{"data":{"access-log-path":"/var/log/nginx/access.log", "access-logrotate-size": "500M", "access-logrotate-round": "20"}}' In this example, {"access-logrotate-size" :"500M"} defines that logs will be rotated once the log size is more than 500 M. {"access-logrotate-round" :"20"} defines that 20 log files will be kept while the older ones will be removed. Define your own rotation size and round number based on your actual business needs. Restart the itom-ingress-controller-nnnnnnn pod so your configurations can take effect. kubectl delete pod -n <suite namespace> itom-ingress-controller-nnnnnnn
contentLower: follow the steps below to implement log rotation so that logs won't use up all storage on the node. patch itom-ingress-controller-conf to enable log rotation with desired rotation size and round number. below is an example. namespace=`kubectl get namespace | grep itsma | cut -f1 -d " "` kubectl patch cm itom-ingress-controller-conf -n ${namespace} -p '{"data":{"access-log-path":"/var/log/nginx/access.log", "access-logrotate-size": "500m", "access-logrotate-round": "20"}}' in this example, {"access-logrotate-size" :"500m"} defines that logs will be rotated once the log size is more than 500 m. {"access-logrotate-round" :"20"} defines that 20 log files will be kept while the older ones will be removed. define your own rotation size and round number based on your actual business needs. restart the itom-ingress-controller-nnnnnnn pod so your configurations can take effect. kubectl delete pod -n <suite namespace> itom-ingress-controller-nnnnnnn

title: How to update custom resource settings
content: This topic guides you on how to make changes to your custom resource settings. You might need to update the values of either the resources replicas, CPU, Memory or the nodeSelector of your deployment. The steps below guides you on how to perform this task. Overview To update a value in your custom resource settings, you will first need to get and save your current custom resource settings, and then use a helm command to update the values you wish to update. Use the steps below to update your custom resource settings. Generate a template of customized values.yaml Use these steps to generate and store your current custom settings to a custom-resources-full-values.yaml file. Log on to one of the control plane nodes (embedded Kubernetes) or a bastion node (external Kubernetes). Change to the ESM_Helm_Chart-2x.x/scripts/custom_settings directory. Run the following commands to change the permission run the generateCustomSettings.sh script: chmod u+x generateCustomSettings.sh ./generateCustom

title: Hardware resource consumption for smart virtual agent
content: This topic describes the hardware resource consumption for the training and user input parsing processes for the smart virtual agent functionality. It also lists various limits that are related with hardware consumption, and how to change the limits. In general, the hardware consumption for both training and user input parsing is determined by the following factors: the number of intents, the number of training sentences per intent, the total number of training sentences, the complexity of training sentences, and the language of intents and training sentences. This topic helps you understand how many hardware resources you need to support the smart virtual agent functionality, and how to configure primary models and various limits to achieve optimized performance. title: Enable tab completion of the suite namespace
content: OMT assigns a unique namespace for each SMA suite installation: itsma-xxxxx (xxxxx is a randomly generated string). Although you can run the kubectl get ns command to get the suite namespace, it's more convenient if you enable tab completion of the suite namespace. By doing so, whenever you need to enter the suite namespace in a command, you can simply enter itsma and then press the Tab key on your keyboard. To enable auto completion of the suite namespace by using the Tab key, perform the following steps on each of the control plane nodes and worker nodes: Make sure that OMT is already installed. This is to ensure that you can run the kubectl command. Log in to machine as root or a sudo user. Run the following commands: source <(kubectl completion bash) echo "source <(kubectl completion bash)" >> ~/.bashrc echo "source <(kubectl completion bash)" >>/etc/profile Enter the following command to verify: kubectl get pods -n <suite namespace> For <suite namespace>, enter itsma and then pres

title: Enable a firewall after installation
content: If your firewall was disabled during the suite installation and needs to be enabled after installation, follow the instructions below to enable the firewall on the suite nodes that are up and running. On the control plane node, go to the $CDF_HOME/scripts directory, and run the following command to stop the SMA suite pods: ./cdfctl.sh runlevel set -l DOWN -n <namespace> Where: <namespace> is your suite namespace (for example, itsma1). You can use the global option -f to show more logs during the stop process. Stop the OMT Kubernetes system on the control plane node: cd $CDF_HOME/bin ./kube-stop.sh Enable the firewall on the control plane node: systemctl start firewalld If you have already run firewalld before and want to clear the iptables rules, see the "How to clear iptables rules on each SMA node" section in this document. Configure firewall rules for the required ports of the control plane node. For details, see the "Related topics" section. Disable SELINUX: vim /etc/selinux/config
headings: How to clear iptables rules on each SMA node

title: Get the suite CA certificate
content: The steps to get the suite CA certificate are different depending on whether you have installed a complete certificate chain in the suite or in an external load balancer used for the suite. We recommend that you install a complete certificate chain in a production environment. A properly configured suite should send all intermediate certificates to the client. For more information, see Replace the suite certificate. Using an incomplete certificate chain isn't good in production and is a common misconfiguration that causes an "unable to get local issuer certificate" or "unable to find valid certification path to requested target" error during an SSL/TLS handshake between the client and server. The certificate chain can't be verified back to a local issuer certificate (which means it's in the client's certificate store). Note If you're unsure whether you have a complete certificate chain or not: You can use the procedure of scenario 2 as it also works for scenario 1. (Only if the suite s

title: Enable SSL connections to external PostgreSQL after suite installation
content: When Service Management sends an SSL connection request to an external PostgreSQL server that has SSL enabled, Service Management acts as a client. To enable Service Management to connect to the external PostgreSQL server through SSL, you must import the PostgreSQL CA certificate into Service Management. This can be done either during or after the suite installation. This topic describes how to enable PostgreSQL SSL connections after the suite installation. Additionally, this topic also describes how to replace the PostgreSQL CA certificate file in the suite. Notes: This operation might cause system downtime. Perform this operation in a planned maintenance window. If the PostgreSQL server certificate is about to expire or is no longer valid, you need to replace it with another new certificate on the database server side. If the CA certificate chain of the new certificate is the same as the CA certificate chain of the old certificate, no action is required on the Service Management side

title: Enable direct download of OO RAS and OO Workflow Designer from the Service Management UI
content: The On-Premises Bridge download center provides download links to endpoint resources. In the Operations Orchestration (OO) section, there's a link to the software product website, from which you can search for and then download OO installation files. If your suite is using the OO Containerized, which has the OO RAS and OO Workflow Designer installation and upgrade files embedded in it, you have the option to replace the product website link with direct download links to these embedded installation and upgrade files. Clicking each direct download link will trigger an automatic download of the corresponding installation or upgrade file. You need to use a script available from the ITOM Marketplace to replace the download link. Additionally, this script allows you to replace the download link for all tenants in one go or only for one tenant at one time. Prerequisites Both Service Management and OO Containerized are running. Integration setup between Service Management and OO Containerized

title: Enable the monitoring capability
content: The monitoring capability enables you to monitor your deployment using Prometheus and to display the results using Grafana dashboards. The monitoring capability isn't supported on Red Hat OpenShift. However, you can install an instance of Grafana and enable the monitoring content of OMT and suite on OpenShift to monitor specific metrics. Refer to the section "Enable monitoring content on OpenShift" for more information. Set up persistent volumes Depending on your existing environment, you might need to set up persistent volumes (PVs). If you've set the capability NfsProvisioner=true during OMT installation, the PVs are created automatically and you can skip the step in this section. If you've already enabled some capabilities, you can use the existing PVs as shared resources. If you want to enable the capabilities in an environment with no AppHub chart installed, you should create all the PVs needed for the capabilities. Refer to the "Create a values.yaml file to enable capabilities af

title: Enable TLS connections to external PostgreSQL
content: When sending a TLS connection request to an external PostgreSQL/AlloyDB Omni server that has TLS enabled, UD/UCMDB acts as a client. To enable UD/UCMDB to connect to the external PostgreSQL/AlloyDB Omni server through TLS, you must import the PostgreSQL/AlloyDB Omni CA certificate into UD/UCMDB. This can be done either during or after the UD/UCMDB installation. This topic describes how to enable PostgreSQL/AlloyDB Omni TLS connections when installing UD/UCMDB or after UD/UCMDB is installed. Additionally, this topic also describes how to replace the PostgreSQL/AlloyDB Omni CA certificate file in UD/UCMDB when the certificate is about to expire or is no longer valid. The PostgreSQL/AlloyDB Omni CA certificate (for example, PG_CA.crt) must be in PEM format. The CA certificate can be single-level or multi-level. If multi-level, the CA certificate must include the entire CA certificate chain (the root CA certificate and all intermediate CA certificates). cat thirdCA.crt>>PG_CA.crt cat secon

title: How to collect suite logs
content: The system saves suite logs on persistent volumes. You can collect suite logs manually using the SMA Support Assistant. This solution supports embedded Kubernetes and managed Kubernetes environments with different types of storage such as NFS, EFS, or StorageClass. Prerequisite Follow the instructions here to install the Support Assistant. Collect logs Enter the itom-toolkit container and find the correct log paths by running the following commands on the control plane node or the bastion node: ns=<ESM_NAMESPACE> # Enter container kubectl exec -it $( kubectl get pods -n $ns |grep itom-toolkit | awk '{print $1}' | head -1) bash -n $ns -c itom-toolkit # find the mount path df -h Where <ESM_NAMESPACE> is the unique namespace of the ESM Helm chart deployment. Enter the relevant log paths (see Where to find logs (Helm deployment) ) and find the log files and folders. For example, in a helm deployment, the log path for Smart Analytics is either /var/vols/itom/itsma/logging-volume/smartanalyt

title: How to create and edit a tenant
content: As a suite admin, you can use the Suite Administration Portal (BO) to create or edit a tenant. Create a tenant From the main menu, click Tenants.Click New. In the New tenant dialog box, give all requested information. This dialog box requests values for the basic attributes. Field Description Account Select the account specified for this tenant. Shared service type (Service Management tenant only) The system automatically sets the shared service type of the tenant according to the shared service type of the account: Provider: Provider tenants can manage the business data of managed tenants.Managed: Managed tenants are client tenants hosted by shared service providers. The shared service agents in provider tenant manage the service cases.Standard: Standard tenants are ordinary tenants and are irrelevant to shared service. Backend type Select the Backend Type of the tenant: SMAXService Manager Name Enter the tenant name. The maximum length of a tenant's name is 255 characters. Type Selec

title: Enable self-service password reset for DB users
content: As the suite admin, you can enable the self-service password reset feature for a tenant. Once this feature is enabled, a Forgot your password? link is available on the Service Portal and agent portal login pages, and users of the DB type can click this link to reset their password on their own. Note This feature is only for users of the DB type. This feature doesn't unlock or activate users. A locked or inactive user is still locked or inactive after a password reset. To enable this feature for a tenant, perform the following steps as the suite admin: In Suite Administration, open the tenant record, and click the IdM settings tab to open the IdM Admin Portal. Click Customization on the left pane, and select the FORGOTTEN PASSWORDS tab. Select the Enable Forget Password checkbox. Configure an SMTP mail server for sending password reset emails to users. Complete the following fields: Email Address From: enter an email address, which will be displayed as the sender in the password reset e

title: How to create and edit a customer
content: Create a customer From the main menu, click Customers. Click New. Complete the form with required information. See the Customer details section below. Click Save. Edit a customer From the main menu, select Customers. Click the customer in the ID column to display the selected customer. Click the tab you want to view or edit. See the Customer details section below. The General tab is open by default. Save the changes. Customer details General tab Field Description ID Customer ID. Full Name Full name of the customer. Short Name Short name of the customer. Contact Contact information of the customer. Phone Phone of the customer. Email Email of the customer. Description Description of the customer. Account tab This tab displays the accounts that belong to the customer. For more information on accounts, see Accounts. Related topics Customers

title: How to create an account
content: From the main menu, click Accounts. Click New. In the New account dialog box, provide all requested information. This dialog box requests values for the basic attributes. Field Description Enable suite SSO Suite Single Sign-On (SSO) enables the users to use single identity and password to log in to all connected suite applications. If Enable suite SSO is Yes, the configured authentications of this account are shared by all connected suite applications. For example, if you create a suite SSO enabled account and specify LDAP as the authentication type, this LDAP connection configuration is shared by all connected suite applications. You can only specify one account to enable suite SSO. This field is displayed only when UCMDB is installed in the suite and no account is enabled suite SSO. Authentication type This field appears only when Enable suite SSO is Yes. Specify the authentication type. SAML: User credentials are stored in federated identity providers using SAML protocol. Users with

title: How to edit an account
content: From the main menu, click Accounts. Click the account in the ID column to display the selected account. Click the tab you want to view or edit. See the Account details section below. The General tab is displayed by default. Save your changes. Account details General tab Field Description ID Account ID. Name Account name. User auto-sync Defines whether the system automatically synchronizes users: If this switch is on, the system automatically synchronizes users from LDAP to IdM (every 12 hours), from IdM to Suite Administration (every 2 hours), and from Suite Administration to Service Management (every 2 hours). In addition, when a new user from IdM logs in to the system, the system creates the user in Suite Administration on the fly if the user doesn't exist in Suite Administration. If this switch is off, automatic user synchronization is disabled, and you have to manually synchronize users for the account. Note You can use the Manage Persons API only to update fields other than UPN/Em

title: How to create a user
content: From the main menu, click Users. Click New. In the New User dialog box, provide all requested information. This dialog box requests values for the basic attributes. Field Description Login name Enter the login name of the user. Spaces, tabs, semicolon (;), equal (=), ampersand (&), angle brackets (<>), octothorpe (#), curly brackets ({}), pipe (|), back quote (`), caret (^), tilde (~), percent (%), question mark (?), quotation mark ("), slash (/), square brackets ([]), or two consecutive underscores (_) can't be used in this field. The login name for Integration user must be unique among all user roles in the suite instance. The login name can't be changed after the user is created. If the DB user login identifier field is set to Email for this account, you don't need to set the Login name field. First name Enter the first name of the user. title: Grant IdM permissions to newly-created suite admin users
content: The newly-created suite admin users don't have the permission to access IdM Admin Portal (https://<External_Access_Host>/idm-admin), to grant IdM permissions to them: Log in to IdM Admin Portal as "suite-admin". Click SYSBO organization from the organization list. From the Groups tab, click the administrators group, and then click on the top-right menu to edit it. In the Users section, add those users who need the IdM permissions as Associated Users, click SAVE.

content: Create a license pool From the main menu, click License-pools. Click New. Enter the name and description. Click Save. Edit a license pool From the main menu, select License-pools. Click the license pool in the ID column to display the selected license pool. Click the tab you want to view or edit. See the License pool details section below. Licenses tab This tab displays the licenses added to this pool. For more information on licenses, see Licenses. Assignments tab This tab displays the assignments of this license pool. To add an assignment, click Add, select a license to get the remaining capacity, and then you can assign the available capacity to the tenant that you select. title: Fields
content: The Fields tab, which includes the Fields Editor, enables you to view, add, and edit fields for a record. To access the Fields tab, from the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Studio > Fields. The tab displays the fields for the record type selected in the drop-down list at the top of the page. Related topics Field properties How to create a field and add it to a record type How to edit a field Calculated fields Calculated field templates Generic relationship fields Cross-record field mapping

title: Field properties
content: The Fields tab displays the fields (including calculated fields and associations) for the record type selected in the drop-down list at the top of the page. A field marked with a lock is a locked system field that you cannot edit (except for the Multilingual label property). To view only the custom fields for the record, click Custom.To view only the calculated fields, click Calculated. For more information on calculated fields, see Calculated fields.To view all the fields for the record, click All. The first column of the fields table displays indicator tags for the fields: Analytic field. You can add this field to analytic reports. Operational field. You can add this field to operational reports and operational raw data reports. In addition to fields marked with the tag, the Id field and the Data Domains field can also be used in operational raw reports. When you select a field, its properties appear in the right pane. title: Edit a field
content: The following are the steps to edit a field: From the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Studio > Fields. Select the record type in the drop-down list at the top of the page. Select the field you want to edit. The field properties appear in the right pane. To undo your changes at any time before you have saved the record, click Discard. To edit the field, make the required changes to the properties in the right pane. Name This property is read-only. Domain This property is read-only. System This property is read-only. Multilingual label The label of the field which Service Management displays in the user interface. This field is required. For locked system fields, the only property that can be edited is Multilingual label. Changes made to the Multilingual label property take effect as soon as you click outside of the property, before you click Save. title: Generic relationship fields
content: Service Management includes the following out-of-the-box generic relationship fields to support specific customer needs: IncidentToCompany You can use this to create relationships between incidents and vendors. However, Service Management best practice for assigning an incident to a vendor (company), is to associate the incident with a group - such as an expert group, or a service desk group - that represents the vendor. An OLA Service Agreement measures the time an incident is in a group, if the incident is assigned to such a group. Therefore, if instead the incident is assigned to a vendor (company), service agreements are unable to measure the service level performance of the vendor. RequestToCompany You can use this to create relationships between requests and vendors. However, Service Management best practice for assigning a request to a vendor (company), is to associate the request with a group - such as an expert group, or a service desk group - that represents the vendor. An OL

title: Forms
content: The Forms tab, which includes the Form Editor, enables you to view and edit the forms for a record. To access the Forms tab, from the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Studio > Forms. The tab displays the forms for the record type selected in the drop-down list at the top of the page. If the record has more than one form, you may select the form you want to view or edit, using the drop-down list at the top of the Forms tab. For example, if you select the record type Change, the forms available include the Full Change, New Change, and Preview Change forms. When you select part of a form, its properties appear in the right pane. Related topics Forms overview Form properties How to edit a form

title: Forms overview
content: The forms of a record are the basis for the user interface for the area of the system devoted to that record type. The different forms available for the record are used in different tabs or dialog boxes of that manager. For example, when a user adds a new change record in Change Management, the user interface displays the New Change form. The Involved CIs tab in Change Management displays the changeInvolvedCis form. By default, every record type has the following basic forms: New <record> Full <record> Preview <record> The following table lists the out-of-the-box forms provided for the different modules, with their uses. Forms used in Web user interface Record type Form Module Description Actual Service Full ActualService form SACM > Actual Services View full details of an actual service. title: Field selection rule examples
content: The following examples demonstrate how to formulate rules for each of the field selection rule templates: Define suggested values based on routing definition For the field parameter, select a field from the drop-down list. For the title parameter, enter the name of the subsection in the drop-down list to be displayed in the user interface. For the name parameter, select the routing definition name from the drop-down list. For the parameters parameter, there is one parameter for each lane of the routing definition. For each parameter, enter an Expression Language phrase that returns the required value. For a full list of Expression Language functions, see Expression Language functions and syntax. When the rule runs, it defines the values available to be selected for the selected group field. The values are determined based on the path defined in the selected routing definition. For an example of the business rule, see Routing definition use case - defining suggested values. Define sugge

title: Edit, remove, or disable a business rule
content: The following task describes how to edit, remove, or disable an existing business rule in Studio: Note If you have development and production tenants, all configuration changes must be made on the development tenant. For more information about synchronizing the tenants, see Dev2Prod - How to synchronize your development and production tenants. In the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Studio. In the Processes and Rules tab, select an existing business rule for the record type or for a process, metaphase, phase, or transition.
