title: Enrichment rules
content: The data enrichment feature in the Studio module enables you to enrich records by populating their fields with predefined values when the records satisfy specified conditions. You define enrichment rules for a record type to drive the data enrichment. For example, an enrichment rule can set the asset model, the vendor, and the brand of a device record according to the value populated in the inventoried model attribute of the device. You can apply enrichment rules to records when importing them into Service Management or later, from the grid page for the record type. They can avoid time-consuming manual work by automatically enriching your managed records. An Asset and configuration administrator can define multiple enrichment rules for a record type. When you import records from a CSV file in the Import data tab in Studio or via a synchronization with UCMDB or LDAP, all the enrichment rules defined for the record type automatically run on the imported records. When you run enrichment r

title: Expression Language in notifications
content: Service Management supports embedding Expression Language in the message body to capture dynamic information from fields. You can make email notifications more meaningful if you take advantage of this feature. This example shows how to create an effective notification with embedded expressions in the appropriate fields: ${:entity.Type} details Service: ${:entity.RegisteredForActualService.DisplayLabel} Category: ${:entity.Category.DisplayLabel} Priority: ${:entity.Priority} Status: ${:entity.Status} Description: ${:entity.Description} In the header of the notification, you can refer to the recipient of the notification using the expression current_recipient. Note Once you check the Use group email checkbox, you can't use the phrase current_recipient in the template. At the end of the notification, you can include a direct link to the notification using the expression ${:entity.Link} by one of the following methods: Method 1: Edit the template to insert the code, for example: <a href="$

title: Governance Level Approval
content: This is an approval feature that allows you to create a high level approval. For example, you might set up Governance Level Approval that requires approval for a request where the cost exceeds a specified amount. Governance level approval is enabled for the following record types: Agreement Article Change Idea Proposal Release Request This feature applies to the service and cart request record types, but not to the support request record type. The approval plan runs only once in cases where there are child requests. It doesn't operate on the child requests. Related topics How does Governance Level Approval Work? How to set up Governance Level Approval

title: How Governance Level Approval works
content: Governance Level Approval is a separate approval, created in the Approval definitions part of records administration, which you may apply to certain record types. If there is an existing approval plan applicable to a phase of the record type, Governance Level Approval is merged in to the front of the approval plan. If there is no existing approval plan applicable to the record type, Governance Level Approval constitutes the only approval plan for the record type. For example, this is a Governance Level Approval plan: It specifies that Cost Center manager approval is required if the cost of the request exceeds a specified threshold. This is an example of the approval plan applying to a particular offering: It specifies that the request requires the approval of the manager of the requestor. This is how Service Management merges the two preceding items as the whole approval plan for a request created using that particular offering: It merges the approvals so that, where applicable, the Go

title: Edit an approval definition
content: From the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Studio. Select the record type in the drop-down list at the top of the page. Click the Approval definitions tab. The approval definitions are listed in the left pane. Select an existing definition. The system displays the plan on the right. Hover over any of the nodes and click Edit. You can edit, duplicate and delete nodes, and you can add new nodes. For information about editing the plan, see How to build a task/approval plan. Note Click Discard to discard changes before saving. Save the approval definition. Related topics Approval definitions How to build an approval definition

title: Export data
content: You can export data from the List view of records: Go to the List view of the record type. Click More in the List view toolbar. Select either: Export to CSV. The downloaded file contains raw data. This option exports the Name value for each ENUM/ENUM SET field and the raw numeric date/time value for each Date/Time field. Note: CSV is primarily intended for integrations or for importing into another reporting solution. Export to XLSX. The downloaded file is localized according to the user's language setting in Service Management. This option exports the Display Name value for each ENUM/ENUM SET field and formatted date/time value for each Date/Time field. Note: XLSX is intended for direct consumption in Excel. The export process adds extra columns for entity link fields to uniquely identify them. For example, when a column links to a Location entity, the export includes one column for the display name and another for the display label. Export of rich text columns In the agent interface,

title: Global search
content: To search for a record in Service Management, as a tenant administrator, you must first store and index this record in IDOL. By default, Service Management supports global search for a fixed set of record types (see Search behaviors). The Global search tab in Studio allows you to configure index fields so that you can enable global search for record types that you customized or other out-of-the-box (OOTB) record types that are currently unsearchable. This section describes how to enable global search for custom or other OOTB record types through index field configuration. Enable index field configuration for global search In the main menu of Service Management, go to Administration > Configuration > Application Settings.Toggle on Enable index field configuration for global search. This allows you to add new index fields and enable global search for custom or more OOTB record types.Click Save. Enable global search for a custom or an unsearchable OOTB record type Go to Studio, and then s

title: How to create and delete users or contacts
content: This topic describes how to create a user or contact, and how to delete a contact. Manually create a user or contact From the main menu, select Administration > Master Data > People > People. Click New. Enter the following information: New person information Field Description First name The first name of the person. Last name The last name of the person. Name The Name field is populated by the values entered in the First name and Last name fields. It can also be edited manually. Create user Specify whether you want to create a user record in Suite Administration. Note The field is visible only when the suite admin has enabled the "Manage users in tenant" feature in Suite Administration. Authentication type If you selected Create user, specify the authentication type for the user: DB or LDAP/SAML/OAUTH. Email The person's email address. U

title: How to assign licenses to users
content: All users must have a license assigned to log in to Service Management. When a tenant is created, the tenant license is automatically assigned to the tenant administrator. This tenant license includes a fixed number of individual license slots. The tenant administrator can then assign other users to the license up to the capacity of the license. Each user acquires a license slot when they log in. There are three types of licenses: Named license is a license assigned to a particular user. Concurrent license may be shared by multiple users who are assigned to this type of license. Only one user can be logged on under each license slot of the concurrent license at a given time. The number of concurrent license slots is determined at the tenant level. Multi-tenant Named Users license is the license used for accessing other tenants in a multi-tenant environment. In terms of the license, it functions the same as a named license and not a concurrent license. The type of license is determined

title: Groups
content: If you are an administrator, part of your responsibilities includes creating and managing user groups. Groups are useful for making assignments, identifying Level 1, Level 2, or Level 3 support groups, or assignment groups. After you create a new user, you can add the user to one or more assignment groups. Role assignments can be automatic if you assign one or more roles directly to the group and then add a user to that group. The user inherits those group role assignments. Note: For information on DND groups and how to configure DND authorization, see Configure authorization for Design and Deploy. How to create a group You can create new groups, such as Service Desk or assignment groups. From the main menu, select Administration > Master Data > People > Groups. Click New.Type a group Name. title: How to manage entitlement rules
content: The Entitlement Rules tab of the People module enables you to create entitlement rules. These rules ensure that offerings, knowledge articles, service definitions, categories, and custom themes in the Service Portal are available to relevant audiences in specified locations, belonging to specified user groups, and belonging to a specified company. The entitlement rules apply to these record types in the Service Portal and fields related to the Service Portal, such as the Catalog offering field in Request records. They don't apply in the record type list view. After creating or updating an entitlement rule, it may take several minutes before users can see information entitled to them by their location and user group. Data domain assignments are different from entitlement rules. They are used to restrict access to specific records in a user's view in Service Management. For more information on data domains, see Data domain segmentation. Create an entitlement rule From the main menu, sele

title: Encryption domains
content: Service Management supports the ability to encrypt specific record type fields via the creation of encryption domains. This enables you to restrict access to sensitive information to selected users. You can assign groups to an encryption domain; the members of each assigned group will have access to the fields encrypted in that domain. For each user who accesses the encrypted fields, a passcode and a verification code are required. You can create multiple encryption domains. Each one operates independently. For example, you may want to encrypt sensitive data for changes using Encryption domain 1 and employee data using Encryption domain 2. Each encryption domain requires a separate verification code. (One passcode is valid for all encryption domains.) After you encrypt a field of a record type, you can add it to a form. The data in the field will be visible only to members of the encryption domain who have been verified. It's also possible to encrypt attachments to records. Encrypted f

title: Fixed asset process - Business rules
content: The fixed asset workflow relies on a few simple business rules. Rules repeat from one phase to another when the end user can make a change to a field affected by a business rule during that phase. All processes In the out-of-the-box device workflow, the rules detailed for each of the following events apply to all processes. After change Condition Service Management actions If Net value isn't empty Currency = USD($) If Depreciation scheme is Geometric and Depreciation rate isn't empty Validate Depreciation rate >= 0 and <= 1 Display the fixed asset workflow error message in case of a failure If Depreciation scheme is Sum of digits and Depreciation duration isn't null Validate Depreciation duration > 0 and can be divided by 12 Display the fixed asset workflow error message in case of a failure Rendering Condition Service Management actions If Depreciation scheme isn't Geometric Hide Depreciation rate Related topics Fixed asset workflow Processes and Rules

title: Enable users to edit requests in the Service Portal
content: By default, users can't edit requests in the Service Portal. If you have the appropriate permissions, you can enable users to edit requests in the portal. The following is a use case demonstrating one advantage of such a capability. A user submits a request reporting an issue with mobile phone connectivity. The user adds details of the phone and its operating system. After submitting the request, the user discovers that the phone operating system has automatically been upgraded to the latest version. Therefore, the information in the submitted request is incorrect. The user logs in to the Service Portal, goes to the request tracking page, and corrects the information about the operating system. Assuming Service Management is configured appropriately, the request assignee then receives notification that the user has made a change to the request. The agent reviews the change and continues to work on it. Another use case might be where a user discovers that a previously submitted request

title: Expert recommendation and auto-assignment for ticket handling
content: Agents are often looking for the best expert to assist with a specific issue. For example, identifying the best agent for a request/incident assignment. The Expert recommendation and auto assignment for ticket handling feature opens the possibility to show the relevant experts when you view the request/incident details. Expert recommendation for ticket handling To benefit from this feature, you need to edit the following settings: Enable expert recommendation Log in as a tenant admin. From the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Application Settings. Make sure the Enable expert recommendation for ticket handling option is set to On, and click Save in the upper left corner. You may also turn on Enable the “Call in Teams” action in the expert recommendation widget to display the “Call in Teams” option when you view the recommended experts in request/incident details. Add expertise skills You can add expertise skills by one of the following methods. Method 1: Add expertise

Method 2: Add expertise skills from the Person page
Method 3: Add expertise skills from the user profile

title: Edit categories
content: The Category page shows all categories. From the main menu, select Administration > Master Data > Categories. The Categories page lists all categories arranged in column format. You may search for a category by entering a text string in the search box at the top of the column. Select the category you want to edit. Click the drop-down arrow on the right of the category. Click Edit to edit the category. If required, click Deactivate to make the category inactive, or Activate to make the category active. Click Save. Click Back to return to Categories. Note If you deactivate a category, this automatically also deactivates any of its subcategories. This doesn't affect existing records. However, while the category is inactive, a user will be unable to select it when creating a new record. If you activate a category, this automatically also activates any parent category it has. Related topics How to create a category How to view categories

title: Get support from the community
content: Agent users can get support about how to implement and use Service Management directly from the product UI by simply clicking the Community option from the avatar menu in the agent interface. This option directs agent users to the Service Management community, where they can get help from live videos, discussions, blog posts, and other resources, as well as share their thoughts and experiences. How to customize the community URL Use the steps applicable to your deployment to customize the community URL. Classic deployment Out of the box, the Community option points to the Service Management community. If you want to change the URL to your own, follow these steps: Log in to a control plane node (in an embedded Kubernetes environment) or the bastion node (in a managed Kubernetes environment). Run the following command (replace <suite namespace> with your own namespace such as itsma-ae6li): kubectl edit cm itom-xruntime-infra-config -n <suite namespace> Locate the following line: COMMUNIT
headings: How to customize the community URL

You can either use an existing work schedule time period, or create one. To view existing work schedule time periods: From the main menu, select Plan > Time Period. Service Management displays the available time periods. You can filter the list to view only work schedule time periods. For more information, see Filters. Ensure the work schedule is active. To create a work schedule: From the main menu, select Plan > Time Period. Click New. The New Time period form is displayed. Type the required details. title: Generate report based on PostgreSQL views
content: Service Management built-in reports and dashboards provide a quick and useful way to define many simple operational and analytic reports. Meanwhile, complex reporting and KPI needs such as queries involving many-to-many relations can be better addressed with BI Tools crafted specifically for this purpose. Service Management only supports direct access to the database for the PostgreSQL views. Unless directed by the Support as part of a case investigation or resolution, any other database access is not supported. PostgreSQL view generation PostgreSQL views are generated during the platform start-up. By connecting a third-party tool such as Microsoft Power BI and Tableau directly to your Service Management data, PostgreSQL views can be utilized by a Service Management database user to generate database reports. Note: You don't need to generate or refresh views to get the latest data updates. However, if the data model changes, for example, a new custom field is added, the views need to b

title: Enable EFS encryption
content: Amazon Elastic File System (EFS) supports two forms of encryption for file systems: data encryption in transitrest You can enable data encryption at rest when creating an Amazon EFS file system. You can enable data encryption in transit when you mount the file system. Enable encryption in transit, if OO is already deployed To enable Amazon EFS encryption in transit, you require an Amazon EFS Container Storage Interface (CSI) driver. See the Amazon EFS CSI driver documentation to deploy the Amazon EFS CSI driver for your Amazon EKS cluster. Get the file system ID of the existing Amazon EFS file system. You'll need to enter this file system ID while recreating the persistent volume. On the bastion node, run the following command to stop OO. cd OMT_External_K8s_2x.x-xxx/scripts/ ./cdfctl.sh runlevel set -l DOWN -n <OO_NAMESPACE> Where <OO_NAMESPACE> is the unique namespace of the OO deployment. Use the namespace that you specified in the Create a new deployment for OO in EKS.Wait until al

title: Encrypting passwords
content: You can encrypt a password using the encrypt-password script, which is located in <installation_folder>/designer/bin. Important After using the encrypt-password script, clear the command history. This is because, on a Linux OS, the password parameter will be stored in cleartext under /$USER/.bash_history and accessible by the history command. Encrypt passwords Locate the encrypt-password script, in <installation_folder>/designer/bin. Run the script with the -e -p <password> option, where password is the password you want to encrypt. Note You can either use -p as the flag to encrypt the password or --password. The encrypted password should appear as follows: {ENCRYPTED}<some_chars>. Create a prompt for the password It is recommended to run the encrypt-password script without providing the –p argument. For example: C:\Program Files\Micro Focus\Operations Orchestration Designer\designer\bin>encrypt-password.bat Password <typing will be hidden>: Confirm password <typing will be hidden>: <E

title: Encryption
content: Encryption model OO Workflow Designer supports encryption and hash algorithms to protect sensitive data. Encryption is designed to prevent the exposure and modification of sensitive data, such as passwords, definitions, and so on, in OO Workflow Designer. It is important to use well-known, standard algorithms without known vulnerabilities, in order to prevent decryption by unauthorized persons. For example, SSL is not used, because of known vulnerabilities in the SSL protocol. Static Data All saved passwords are protected using well known algorithms and none are left in clear text. For example, the database passwords are encrypted. Data in-transit OO Workflow Designer uses the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol to encrypt the data between components. Disabling the HTTP port It is recommended to disable the HTTP port, for security reasons, so that the only communication channel will be on TLS and encrypted. Encryption administration Default Configuration Set Symmetric-key algorithm

title: Hardening OO Workflow Designer
content: This topic provides recommendations for safeguarding your OO Workflow Designer deployment from security risks or threats. Some of the most important reasons to secure an application include protecting the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of an organization's critical information. To comprehensively protect your OO Workflow Designer system, it is necessary to secure both OO Workflow Designer and the computing environment (for example, the infrastructure and the operating system) upon which the application runs. The Hardening section provides recommendations to help secure OO Workflow Designer at the application level and does not cover how to secure the infrastructure within the customer environment. The user is solely responsible for understanding the infrastructure or environment and applying the respective hardening policies. This topic describes how to configure security hardening for OO Workflow Designer and includes the following topics. Security hardening recommendati

title: Handle dynamic values in option properties of service designs
content: Starting with this release, the following aren't supported: The use of .jsp scripts to set dynamic values in option properties: In the previous releases, you could use .jsp scripts to dynamically fetch the options in the configuration options of service designs or user operations. You will need to convert the existing .jsp scripts to their equivalent .js to continue using these functionalities. After upgrading, all the .jsp file name's will be renamed to <jsp-filename>-MIGRATED.js and the contents of the JSP are commented out. The use of ResourceAlias to set dynamic values in option properties: You need to replace ResourceAlias with the method appropriate to your use case as below. Use of ResourceAlias to read resource sync data - Replace with executeXPathQueryOnSyncData Use of ResourceAlias to fetch data from an external source - Replace with ESMEndpoint Guidelines to develop equivalent .js scripts Replace ResourceSync with executeXPathQueryOnSyncData service method of CSAIntegrationH

title: How to update the Audit service passwords
content: The Audit service uses the following users and passwords. Audit database user and password: Audit service uses the Audit service database user to connect to the audit database. IdM transport user and password: Audit service uses the Audit service IdM transport user to connect to IdM and to run some APIs. This user should be present in the IdM before Audit service deployment. IdM super user and password: Audit service uses the Audit service IdM super user to connect to IdM and to run some APIs. This user should be present in the IdM before Audit service deployment. If you or someone changes any of these passwords, You might see an authentication error when accessing Audit service. Audit service is unable to connect to IdM. Audit service is unable to connect to the database. The Audit UI doesn't show the data. When you check the logs, you will be able to see an authentication error. You have to then update these passwords in the Kubernetes container and Audit vault. The following section

Mike - Security agent Prepares and delivers an ID badge for Pete. Pete -New employee Uploads a photo for his ID badge and completes the required paperwork. Prerequisites You have deployed the HR Content package. The package contains the offering bundle, email templates, and survey that are required by this use case. title: HR SM use case: Request for remote country work
content: Pete, an employee, wants to temporarily work remotely from a foreign country after spending some of his annual leave there. To do this, he must first request and obtain approval from his line manager and org owner. This use case demonstrates how Service Management can automate the handling of formal approvals and process tasks related to an HR request. The following personas are involved in this use case. Persona Responsibilities Pete - Employee Makes the request for remote country work and confirms his return. Paul - Manager Approves the request for remote country work Lynn - Org owner Approves the request for remote country work Eve - HR agent Closes the ticket when Pete confirms his return. Prerequisites You must have deployed the HR Content package. The package contains the Request Remote Country Work Agreement service offering that is required to fulfill Pete's request. title: Filters
content: Filters help you filter record lists or define filters for a report. You can use the following methods to create a filter. Filter by field value Click the Add filter button. In record lists, this button is located above the list of records.When you create a report, this button appears when you select the record type for the report. If there are more records than the Maximum query size value defined in the tenant settings from Suite Administration (default: 10, 000), the Filter wizard is displayed. The Add Filter button is located above the Filter wizard. For information about using the Filter wizard, see Filters below. From the Select field list, select a field and a value, by which to filter the list: List fields Record fields Text fields Date fields The fields that are initially available in the filter are searchable fields. title: History
content: The History tab enables you to view all the updates made to the selected record. The following details are displayed: Column Description Updated on The update time of the record Updated by The user who performed the update Details The details of the update Note: The changes to the Role of a Person or Group aren't shown on the History tab. The History tab can display up to 250 history records. Important Service Management only supports direct access to the database for the PostgreSQL views. Unless directed by the Support as part of a case investigation or resolution, any other database access isn't supported. title: How to use duration based calculated fields in reports
content: You can use duration based calculated fields in analytic reports to help present the information you need, in the way you want. The following sections discuss some of the practical considerations and techniques. Duration and calculated fields Let’s assume you want to know how long change records stay in the Plan phase. To find this out, you create a calculated field using the Phase duration template, and selecting the Plan phase. You call the calculated field Duration of Plan phase. Having created the calculated field, you then create a report displaying changes, and using this field. It's likely the report will include a number of changes for which the Duration of Plan phase is zero. What does that mean? The possible explanations for Duration of Plan phase being zero are as follows: The change record never was in the Plan phase. The change record is still in the Plan phase. The way that Service Management calculates duration is to measure the time between entering and exiting the sele

title: How to design category tiles for the Service Portal
content: The category tiles on the Service Portal home page can be comprised of several graphic designs. It's recommended to mix and match these designs for an interesting and attractive look. You can use available background images and solid background colors. To access the category settings, from the main menu, select Plan > Service Catalog > Categories. The settings are per category so you must enter each category and expand the Category display settings. Note Setting default open tab per category isn't supported. If your suite is upgraded from previous version, tenant admin may need to manually remove the Default open tab field in your category form if you still see this field in the UI. You may set default open tab for all categories through Service Portal Settings > Feature Settings > Category page type. title: How to create a time period record
content: Note When creating a time period record, please be aware of the Daylight Saving Time that is adopted by your country. It's important to note that Daylight Saving Time varies from country to country, and some countries choose not to apply it. Therefore, the impact on the Start Time/End Time brought by Daylight Saving Time can't be taken into account automatically. Please manually adjust your time period according to it. From the main menu, select Plan > Time Period. Service Management displays the available time periods. Service Management includes the following time period views: Holidays & events Maintenance & blackouts Work schedules Click New. Complete the General section. This section contains basic information about the time period. Field Description Title A title for the time period. Best practice: choose a meaningful, descriptive, and relatively short title. Titles are often the only identification used in selection lists and in other areas to identify components. Description A

title: How to activate a time period record
content: Notes You must have the appropriate permissions to be able to activate a time period. On call shift is a special type of time period, once an on-call shift is activated, its state will always stay Active. That is, it cannot be moved forward to Retired or back to Draft. To activate a time period record means changing its status, as shown in the workflow snapshot at the top of the time period, from draft to active. From the main menu, select Plan > Time Period. Select the time period record. Click the record identifier in the ID column to display the selected record. Click , then Save. Related topics Time Period Management Time periods How to create a time period record How to edit a time period record How to retire a time period record

title: How to retire a time period record
content: Note You must have the appropriate permissions to be able to retire a time period. If you retire a time period, it no longer displays in Service Management modules. For example, a retired time period doesn't appear in the Change Calendar. On call shift is a special type of time period, once an on-call shift is activated, its state will always stay Active. That is, it cannot be moved forward to Retired or back to Draft. To retire a time period record means changing its status, as shown in the workflow snapshot at the top of the time period, from active to retired. From the main menu, select Plan > Time Period. Select the time period record. Click the record identifier in the ID column to display the selected record. Click , then Save. Related topics Time Period Management Time periods How to create a time period record How to edit a time period record How to activate a time period record

title: Edit a Service Level Target definition record
content: A change in circumstances or a change to the Service Level Agreement record can require changes to the associated Service Level Target definition record. For example, you might change the work schedule that applies to the agreement. You can change a value in a Service Level Target definition, but make sure that you understand the impact of the changes. If you change or update a record, Service Management applies the changes correctly to any calculation in progress. For example, the priority in an incident is changed from Medium to Critical, Service Management adjusts the calculation in progress to apply this new value. If you change the actual service or offering assigned to a record, the Service Level Target definition might change or even become obsolete. If the Service Level Target definition changes, the Service Level Target calculation in progress is cleared, and any new or changed target definition calculations begin. In this case, the time already spent is included in the new ta

title: Environment workflow
content: This page explains the environment workflow and the steps to perform the following tasks: View workflow and current phase of environment Change phase of environment Environment workflow The environment workflow describes the different metaphases and phases in the lifecycle of an environment. Metaphases represent broad stages in the lifecycle, while phases are the specific steps within each stage. The environment lifecycle consists of the following metaphases: Preparation Operation Ended (End) The following figure shows the environment workflow. The following sections describes phases within each metaphase. Preparation Phase Description Allowed transitions Transition type Ready After you create an environment, it is in the Ready phase by default. Ready to In use, Ready to Inactive Manual Operation Phase Description Allowed transitions Transition type In use Move the environment to the In use phase when you plan to run product instances on the environment. In use to Deactivating Manual D

title: Entitlement workflow
content: This page explains entitlement workflow and the steps to perform the following tasks: View workflow and current phase of entitlement Change phase of entitlement Entitlement workflow The entitlement workflow describes the different metaphases and phases in the lifecycle of an entitlement. Metaphases represent broad stages in the lifecycle, while phases are the specific steps within each stage. The product instance lifecycle consists of the following metaphases: Preparation Operation Ended (End) The following figure shows the entitlement workflow. The following sections describes phases within each metaphase. Preparation Phase Description Allowed transitions Transition type Ready After you create an entitlement, it is in the Ready phase by default. Ready to In use, Ready to Inactive Manual Operation Phase Description Allowed transitions Transition type In use Move the entitlement to the In use phase when you are ready to provide support for product instances covered under the entitlement

title: Edit a portfolio record

title: How to send a survey to collect application information
content: To collect basic information about applications, you need to send the out-of-the-box Application Cloudification Survey to the application owners. The system assesses the information and then uses an algorithm to provide cloud solution recommendations. From the main menu, select Plan > Application Portfolio > Optimizations. Service Management displays a list of optimization records. Select the optimization record that you want to assess. To filter the record list, click the Add filter button. For more information, see Filters. Click the optimization record identifier in the ID column to display the selected record, or click Edit in the optimization preview panel. By default, the optimization record is displayed with the General tab selected. Complete all required fields under the Summary section. title: Executive Summary
content: The executive summary is a visual tool that helps project portfolio managers and executives to view the overall status of the projects, programs, and project portfolios that they manage. The executive summary provides a list of projects, programs, and project portfolios, and shows the key statistics and charts of these contents. From the main menu, select Plan > Project & Management. Service Management displays the Executive Summary. If defined, the health status is indicated next to the name of the item and above the charts. For each item in which data is defined, a set of charts is displayed, showing the following: Planned cost (per month) - displays the total cost, regardless of the cost type. Note that the cost displayed is for the item itself, and not the cost of the item's aggregated contents. Budget (per type) - displays up to the four budget types with the highest budgets individually, and aggregates the remaining budget types, if any, into a single entry. For more information,

title: How to relate change records
content: Service Management records are often linked to one another, because you can't always complete a change without investigating incidents or their causes, or putting other changes in motion. Service Management lists related records in a separate tab on the change form. The Related records tab enables you to review, create, and delete relationships among Service Management records. The bracketed number in the tab label displays the number of related records for the current record. There are three types of related records: Causes of the record are other changes, incidents, or problems that triggered the current record. Example: an employee requests a certain change to an email account. The request triggered an incident because there is an email server outage. You can't complete the change until the incident status is closed. Effects of the record are other changes, incidents, or problems that are the result of the current record. Example: the incident to repair the email server outage gener

title: How to use the Change Calendar
content: If you have the appropriate permissions, you can use the Change Calendar to work on scheduling of changes. From the main menu, select Build > Change > Calendar. The Change Calendar is displayed. Note The Change Calendar recognizes and enforces change workflow rules. For example, changes must be scheduled to occur after the current time. If you breach the rules, the change representation displays in red, and a Health Indicator icon appears, displaying the number of validation error messages. Click the icon to view the messages. The calendar also recognizes the following restrictions about change schedules: Changes should be scheduled to occur in a maintenance time period (or "window") Changes should not be scheduled to occur in a blackout period If you breach either or both of these restrictions, a warning icon is displayed. You can do the following tasks in the Change Calendar: Deal with an unscheduled change Reschedule a change Reschedule downtime for a change Deal with a change outsi

title: Filter records in the Change Calendar
content: Filters help you reduce the number of records in a record list. Select Build > Change > Calendar. Click the Add filter button. From the Select field list, choose the field that you want to be the overall filter criteria. For example, choose Priority to filter records by a specific priority value. Choose the field value. Repeat steps 1–4 to add more filter criteria. Service Management displays only those records that meet the filter criteria. Click Clear all to remove all filters. title: How change collision detection works
content: If you have correctly set up the change collision detection feature, a user is unable to save a change that collides according to the rule configuration. The system displays a warning message, and the user must reschedule the change to avoid all collisions before the user can save the record. Note The change collision detection feature takes into account only active changes. Related topics Change collision detection How to enable change collision detection
contentLower: if you have correctly set up the change collision detection feature, a user is unable to save a change that collides according to the rule configuration. the system displays a warning message, and the user must reschedule the change to avoid all collisions before the user can save the record. note the change collision detection feature takes into account only active changes. related topics change collision detection how to enable change collision detection

title: Enable change collision detection
content: To enable change collision detection, you must add a business rule to the After change section of the Change process. If you want to also detect change collisions affecting the same device, you must also add a business rule to the Before adding relationship section of the Change process. For more information, see the following sections. The business rule added to the Before adding relationship section of the Change process, checks collisions between change records with matching times when there is a change to their involved device. For example, assume two change records have matching times but different involved devices. At a later date, if one of the change records is modified so that they have the same involved device, the business rule generates a collision alert. However, where there is the appropriate business rule in the After change section, but not in the Before adding relationship section, change collision is only detected when start or end times are modified. Change collision

title: Edit a change template
content: You can edit a template when it requires an update, but you can't change the template type. From the main menu, select Build > Change > Templates. Select the change template. Click the template title to open the template record. Edit any field in the existing template. If you change the value in a field with an existing value, that value appears in every new change where you apply the template. If the updated value isn't appropriate for all changes that use the template, the end user has to change it. Complete the Template details. Field Description Title A title for the template. You may use a maximum of 30 characters for the title. Best practice: Choose a meaningful, descriptive, and relatively short title. Titles are often the only identification used in selection lists and in other areas to identify component. Type This field is auto-completed with the template type: change, incident, or problem. title: Emergency changes
content: An emergency change is an expedited process to implement emergency changes to the production environment. A user with the appropriate permissions can open an emergency change. (By default, Incident and Change Coordinators and Managers have these permissions.) An emergency change uses a dedicated, shortened approval plan. Service Management notifies you when there is an update to an emergency change. For example, there is a notification when Service Management opens, updates, or closes an emergency change. Related topics ITIL and Change Management Change input and output Change Management KPIs Change Management and other modules

title: Hot Topic Analytics for knowledge articles
content: Hot Topic Analytics enables you, the Service Management support agent, to analyze questions and requests submitted by the Service Portal users, as well as the types of information that other Service Portal users are looking for. The analysis considers questions asked by the Service Portal users, as well as search strings that were entered by the users. It also analyzes how users treated the search results that were generated, that is, which search results were further drilled into, and so on. The hot topic maps provide an analysis of important interest areas that have arisen through the Service Portal. For more information, see How to analyze Service Portal knowledge searches. From the analytics that are displayed, you can in turn create knowledge articles based on the results generated, providing a more directed source of information for future user searches. content: If you edit an article model, the changes have no effect on existing article records, but affect all new article records created after the edit. title: Guidelines for preparing knowledge articles for importing to Service Management
content: This section provides guidelines for preparing knowledge articles for conversion to HTML format. Follow these guidelines to optimize the appearance of your imported knowledge articles in Service Management. Use only the tags mentioned in this section. Using other tags may cause your articles to render incorrectly when uploaded. Do not use any Javascript code. Do not use <l>, , , or <body> tags. These are automatically generated for you. The following tags are supported: Bold Use <strong> Do not use <bold> Italics Use <em> Do not use <i> Images Use the <img> tag. Service Management automatically sizes your images correctly across all screen sizes and devices. Do not manually assign a specific width or height to the images. Image code already contains a link that leads to the image itself to view it at full size. Do not provide links to the images as this overrides this functionality. Line breaks Use <br> Example: Between an image and a line of text. Links To create a link

title: Get started with SACM
content: Before you use Service Asset and Configuration Management, it's helpful to learn a little about the user interface, the model that governs asset management in Service Management, the device and service workflow, Native SACM, and the basic ITIL v3 principles that are the foundation of Service Asset and Configuration Management. Related topics SACM user interface Configure Service Asset and Configuration Management Service Asset and Configuration Management model SACM and ITIL Native SACM

title: Enhanced CI aging solution with Native SACM
content: If Native SACM is enabled, the enhanced CI aging feature enables you to manage the lifecycle of CIs. If Universal Discovery hasn't discovered a CI for a predefined period of time, the system sets its discovery state to Purgeable in UD/UCMDB rather than auto-purges it in the traditional way. Accordingly, the CI's missing flag will be automatically set and one email notification will be sent to the CI owner for confirmation, the owner can then decide if he/she needs to retire the purgeable CI either manually or automatically through workflows. Likewise, if a CI is provisioned by a Service Design through the DND integration, the CI will be created in UCMDB and then synchronized to Service Management. At this point, the provision state field is set to Provisioned, which indicates that it is provisioned by DND. Later when it is decommissioned by DND, the provision state will be set to Purgeable. Then, for Devices and System Elements, the CI will be automatically moved to the Retired or Ende

title: How to receive assets in Service Asset and Configuration Management
content: You can receive assets as part of the standard SACM workflow (and add them as SACM records) within each of the relevant parts of Service Management. For example, you can use the Devices part to receive devices, the Infrastructure & Peripherals part to receive infrastructure assets, and the Enterprise Assets part to receive enterprise assets. However, Service Management also allows you to receive multiple types of assets at the same time. You can receive assets from SACM Home or Stock Management, either manually, or by importing the data from an electronic version of an advance ship notice (ASN), or similar documentation. You can import up to 10,000 records at a time, either manually or in a single ASN file. You can import up to 40,000 records within 24 hours on a single tenant. You must have Advanced import permission to receive assets. From SACM Home From the main menu, select Build > Service Asset & Configuration. Click the Receive assets link in the upper right corner. The Receive a

title: How to check assets have been added to SACM
content: You can check if asset records have been added properly to SACM in the following ways: In the relevant part of SACM From SACM Home, select Devices or Infrastructure & Peripherals, as appropriate. Search for the assets, for example, by filtering the records by Model and External PO number. In the Received assets report From the main menu, select Build > Service Asset & Configuration. Click the Received report link in the upper right corner. The Received assets report is displayed. The table displays file import history with information including the status of each import, the creation and finish time of the import, and the number of successful, warning, and failed records in the import. Click the record identifier in the ID column to display the selected record. Select End or Cancel from the drop-down list on the top right corner of the General tab. Click Save on the toolbar. Method 2: end or cancel a reservation through Service Request To end or cancel a reservation through Service Request: From the main menu, select Run > Service Request. title: Group access to subscription
content: When you submit a request based on a cloud offering or modify an existing cloud subscription, you can enable group access to subscription on the request. This opens the possibility to assign your groups to the subscription as well. If the groups are assigned to the subscriptions under different access levels, all members of those groups will be able to operate, modify, cancel or have full access to that subscription according to the assigneed access level. The initial requestor person will stay as the subscriber of the subscription. Enable group access to subscription In Service Portal, when you submit a request based on a cloud offering or modify an existing cloud subscription, you can turn on Enable group access to subscription to define the group access, including Full access,  Operate subscription, Modify subscription and Cancel subscription. When the Enable group access to subscription option is Off, only the subscriber has full access (operate, modify and cancel) to the cloud sub

title: Enterprise assets
content: Enterprise Asset Management is available for Service Management Premium and Asset Management licenses only. Enterprise assets mainly refer to the non-IT assets owned or used within your organization to support its operation and seamless function. Through the application of Enterprise Asset Management (EAM), we provide a centralized platform to oversee the end-to-end lifecycle of your enterprise assets. This will optimize resource allocation, minimize downtimes, and extend asset lifespans. For each enterprise asset, you can define its Subtype and Process type based on specific categories and their lifecycles. Out of the box, there're three process types of enterprise assets, and each has its corresponding workflow: Full-ownership assets mean the organization or individual has complete ownership and responsibility for the entire lifecycle of the asset. See Full-ownership assets workflow. Consumable assets need to be disposed of considering the legal, environmental, or regulatory requirem

title: Enterprise Asset roles and permissions
content: There are specific roles associated with Enterprise Asset. Service Management uses role-based permissions to enable you to complete a task that's appropriate to your role. The tenant administrator manages and assigns these permissions. For new tenants, these permissions are automatically included in the default roles. However, for existing tenants, you must manually add these permissions to all OOB Roles listed in the table. The following OOB roles are provided with Enterprise Asset. Role Responsibilities Asset & Configuration Administrator Create, view, update, delete, and manage enterprise assets Asset & Configuration Manager Create, view, and update enterprise assets Change Approver View enterprise assets Change Assignee View enterprise assets Change Coordinator View enterprise assets Change Manager View enterprise assets Change Owner View enterprise assets Change Process Owner View enterprise assets Change Requestor View enterprise assets Change Task Assignee View enterprise assets

title: Enterprise assets workflow
content: This section describes the metaphases and subordinate phases in the life cycle of enterprise asset. The workflow of enterprise assets varies based on the their process types: Full Ownership, Consumable, and Stationary. The workflow relies on business rules. Rules repeat from one phase to another when the end user can make a change to a field affected by a business rule during that phase. For more information about the out-of-the-box business rules defined for the enterprise asset workflow, see Enterprise asset process - Business rules. Full Ownership Metaphase: Unavailable The asset enters into the system and is still awaiting delivery. Phase Transition Description New Automatic New is a starting point. Next phase: Awaiting Delivery Awaiting Delivery Manual The enterprise asset is in transit from a vendor or another provider. title: Enterprise asset business rules
content: You can define business rules within a specific asset model. The rules run in the enterprise asset workflow for enterprise asset records based on the selected model. These business rules can be used to make a user option mandatory, hidden, or to control values displayed in the user option fields and any fields in the enterprise asset based on the model. You can define the rules to run in connection with one of the following process events: Process event Description Before change The rule is running before the data is updated. After change The rule is running after the data is updated. Rendering forms The rule is running when a form is opened. After applying changes The rule is running after the change is committed. In each process event, you can define the rule to run either before or after the general record business rules. To add an enterprise asset model business rule: From the main menu, select Build >Service Asset & Configuration. From SACM Home, select Asset Models. Select the re

title: Enterprise asset subtypes
content: Enterprise Asset Management is available for Service Management Premium and Asset Management licenses only. Enterprise asset subtypes function as nested classifications within broader asset categories. They offer a more detailed and specific management of diverse asset types within an organization. By defining subtypes, you can attain a higher level of control over the asset management processes and align with the unique requirements of different asset types. For example, Office Supplies, Lifting equipments, Furniture and fixtures, Vehicles, Building and enclosures. Related topics Enterprise Asset Subtype roles and permissions Create an enterprise asset subtype Edit an enterprise asset subtype Enterprise asset subtypes workflow

content: There are specific roles associated with Enterprise Asset Subtype. Service Management uses role-based permissions to enable you to complete a task that's appropriate to your role. The tenant administrator manages and assigns these permissions. The following OOB roles are provided with Enterprise Asset Subtype. Software Manager View enterprise assets Stockroom Admin View enterprise assets Review the individual permission assignments for each role in Administration > Master Data > People > Roles. Related

title: Edit an enterprise asset subtype
content: You can edit an enterprise asset subtype record to add new information or change existing information. You can edit multiple records simultaneously by selecting them in the grid and updating them in the Preview pane on the right. For more information, see Mass update. From the main menu, select Build >Service Asset & Configuration> Enterprise Asset Subtypes. Select the enterprise asset subtype record you want to edit. To filter the record list, click the Add filter button. For more information, see Filters. Click the record identifier in the Id column to display the selected record. By default, the enterprise asset subtype record is displayed with the General tab selected. Click the tab you want to edit or view. Tab Description General Displays details of the selected record. For more information, see the General tab section. Workflow Displays the workflow metaphase and phase for the selected enterprise asset. For more information about workflows, see Enterprise asset subtype workflow.

title: Enterprise asset subtypes workflow
content: This section describes the metaphases and subordinate phases in the life cycle of enterprise asset subtype. Metaphase: Draft Phase Transition Description Draft Manual The enterprise asset subtype is in the draft stautus. Next phase: Active or Retired Metaphase: Active Phase Transition Description Active Manual The enterprise asset subtype is available for selection. To make the enterprise asset subtype retired, manually transition it to the Retired phase. To modify the enterprise asset subtype, manually transition it to the Draft phase. Next phase: Retired or Draft. Metaphase: Retired (End) Phase Transition Description Retired Manual The enterprise asset subtype isn't available for selection. Next phase: None Related topics Create an enterprise asset subtype Edit an enterprise asset subtype Enterprise asset subtypes

title: Export data from a survey
content: After you receive responses to a survey, you can export some or all of the raw data in XLSX format. There is a delay of up to one day in the retrieval of your survey response data. To remove this delay, you can manually retrieve the response data. For details, see Retrieve survey responses manually. From the main menu, select Build > Survey. Service Management displays the available surveys. Click the record identifier in the ID column to display the selected record. Click on the main toolbar. The Export survey responses dialog box is displayed. Note By default, the following items are selected when this dialog box opens for the first time for a particular survey: All questions The ID, name and email of the participant (if this information is included in the survey) The ID and title of the record type (if this information is included in the survey) The answer submission time, survey version, and survey ID in the General survey fields section. If you have previously exported data for a

title: Hot Topic Analytics for surveys
content: Hot Topic Analytics in Survey Management enable you to analyze the answers to text questions in surveys. You can analyze each text question individually, and filter by the answer time or by specific values related to the primary rating question of a survey. The hot topics map displays answers received in the current execution cycle. For example, if a survey is in its second execution cycle but has not yet received answers, you will not be able to search through the results until you receive answers in that cycle. To analyze a specific topic, click it in the hot topics map. To read the actual response to a survey question, click the result in the displayed list. Related topics Survey Management workflow How to manage hot topic analytics

Vendor Catalog Administrator creates a vendor catalog titled HP Laptop for vendor Hewlett Packard. For more information about creating a vendor catalog, see Create and manage vendor catalogs. Vendor Catalog Administrator adds a vendor catalog item HP EliteBook 850 to HP Laptop. For more information about creating a vendor catalog item, see Create and manage vendor catalog items. Vendor Catalog Administrator publishes the item as an offering with the display label "Request HP EliteBook 850". For more information about publishing a vendor catalog as offering, see Publish a vendor catalog item as offering. title: HR Support Request workflow
content: This section describes the metaphases and subordinate phases in the life cycle of an HR Support Request. The workflow relies on business rules. Rules repeat from one phase to another when the end user can make a change to a field affected by a business rule during that phase. Metaphase: Classification Example: a request is submitted for information about vacation entitlement. There is no parent cart request. The phase automatically transitions to Classify. Phase Transition Description Log Automatic Log is the starting point for requests. The result of the phase is the successful creation of a request. The phase automatically transitions to Classify when either of the following apply: It has no parent cart request. It's notdependent on the approval of its parent cart request. The phase automatically transitions to Close when its parent cart request is denied. Next phase: Classify, or Close Log Manual The agent can manually transition the request to Abandon if the request is no longer va

title: Effect of public requests on other features
content: If you configure public requests, you should note the following. Request on behalf If a user creates a public request for another person, public scope looks at the Location and Organization of the other person. Shopping cart An offering may have an Allow public value of Optional. When a user adds such an offering to the shopping cart, Service Portal doesn't ask if the user wants to share the request the system will create. Related topics How to create a public request in the Service Portal How to set up public requests How to view and follow a public request in the Service Portal

title: Escalate an incident record
content: As an Incident Manager or Incident Coordinator, you can escalate an incident record to reduce the resolution time, add expert resources, or both to meet Service Level Target objectives. Your organization may have different teams to resolve different types of incidents. From the main menu, select Run > Incident > Incidents. Service Management displays a list of all incidents. Select the incident record that you want to edit from the list of incidents. To filter the record list, click the Add filter button. For more information, see Filters. Click the record identifier in the ID column to display the selected record. Expand the Assignment section. Select an Assignment group or an Assignee (or both). Click Save on the toolbar. The incident is then reassigned to a member of the appropriate team. Related topics How to create an incident record How to close an incident record How to delete an incident record How to edit an incident record How to relate incident records Incident Management pr

title: Edit an incident template
content: You can edit a template when it requires an update, but you can't change the template Type. From the main menu, select Run > Incident > Templates. Service Management displays a list of all template records. Select the incident template. Click the template title to open the template record. Edit any field in the existing template. If you change the value in a field with an existing value, that value will appear in every new incident where you apply the template. If the updated value isn't appropriate for all incidents that use the template, the end user will have to change it. Edit any field in any section: Incident details Classification Assignment Resolution Click Save. title: First touch solutions
content: An immediate resolution is the shortest incident workflow. When the person who creates an incident can resolve an incident immediately, the incident doesn't have to go through the typical process of assignment, validation, and closure. Immediate resolution might be one of the following: A solution applied to a similar incident A published workaround A solution documented in a knowledge article You can describe the first touch solution in the Solution field. For more information, see How to add an incident. For more information on First touch solutions and Incident Management KPIs, see Incident Management Key Performance Indicators. Related topics Incident Management ITIL process Learn more about Incident Management Incident solution matching

title: Hot Topic Analytics for Incidents and Problems
content: Hot Topic Analytics in Problem Management use the advanced search and analytics capabilities in Service Management to enable you to view and analyze incidents, and to create problem records based on those incidents. The hot topics map provides trend analysis so you can visually identify incidents that share common issues. The map in Problem Management includes all incidents in the system. It doesn't include any other record type. In the filter above the map, you can't select any other record types as it defaults to Incidents, but you can select a service type as a secondary filter using the Add filter button . You can drill down into the map and view the specific incidents related to an issue. In the list of incidents on the right, you can select multiple incidents to create a problem based on those similar incidents. The fields in the created problem are populated by the information only from the first incident selected. All other incidents become the new problem's related links. When

title: How to set up On-Call Schedule Management
content: Before you set up this feature, you must: Ensure it's enabled. For more information, see Enable On-Call Schedule Management. Set up the relevant groups and the members of the group. For more information, see People. Important You must ensure the On-Call Schedule permission is enabled for the roles of those users who will administer On-Call Schedule Management. For more information, see How to edit role permissions. To set up On-Call Schedule Management, configure the following: Working hours. For more information, see How to set up working hours. Vacations. For more information, see How to add a vacation. Shifts. For more information, see How to set up on-call shifts. Assignment strategy. For more information, see How to set up assignment strategy. Related topics How to set up assignment strategy How to set up on-call shifts How to add a vacation How to set up working hours

title: How license consumption is calculated
content: This section describes how SAM calculates license consumption for on-premises products. Calculation process for on-premises products After you trigger a license compliance calculation job for on-premises products, SAM processes the job in the following steps. Step 1: Parse job parameters The SAM job executor parses parameters in the job context record, such as the product you want to calculate and the data source you want to use. SAM automatically generates these job parameters based on your operations on the UI. Step 2: Fetch license data SAM retrieves license data based on the parsed parameters and uses the retrieved data to build an in-memory license pool. Step 3: Fetch CI data from UD/UCMDB Based on the parsed parameters, SAM retrieves CI data from UD/UCMDB through an API. Step 4: Organize CI and configuration data SAM organizes the retrieved CI data by calculation unit, and then passes the organized CI and configuration data as input context. Step 5: Calculate license consumption

title: Financial Management
content: Service Management's Financial Management module helps you manage money in an efficient and effective way, so as to align with enterprise strategy and achieve business objectives. It assists with budget planning and the execution, monitoring, and control of financial resources. The Financial Management module allows you to record or refer to financial details of the following: Fixed assets, such as accounting codes, depreciation, and residual value Reconciled IT assets, including devices, infrastructure and peripherals, and fixed asset licenses Cost centers, such as effective date, manager, and reporting center Cost types Financial assets, including account codes, budgets, budget centers, budget types, and budget lines Assets related to financial scheduling, including accounting periods and fiscal years View expense lines generated based on configured cost allocation rules or created manually with expense line capability enabled. Difference between Accounting codes and Account code: Ac

title: Financial Management roles and permissions
content: There are specific roles associated with financial management and its components. Service Management uses permissions based on roles for task alignment with your assigned role. The tenant administrator manages and assigns these permissions. The following role is by default assigned to Financial Management. Role Responsibilities Financial Manager Able to add, edit, or delete budget lines in projects, programs, or portfolios Able to add or edit cost allocation rules Able to create or view expense lines Maintains the budget type list Maintains the financial metadata, including the financial calendar and chart of accounts Maintains the virtual financial organization and objects, including cost centers and cost types, budget centers and budget types Review the individual permission assignments for each role in Administration > Master Data > People > Roles. Related topics Roles

title: Fixed Assets
content: A fixed asset is an asset that will be in use for a long term (typically more than a year). You can capitalize (CAPEX) and depreciate it over several years in the general ledger. The decision of whether an asset will be a fixed asset or not is often related to the general ledger, country regulations, and the customer decision. Fixed Assets enable you to view or refer to financial details of assets, such as acquisition cost, depreciation and residual value, and disposal information. The feature helps you manage your assets from a financial perspective. Related topics Fixed asset workflow How to create a fixed asset record How to edit a fixed asset record How to import fixed asset records

title: Fixed asset workflow
content: This section describes the metaphases and subordinate phases in the life cycle of a fixed asset. The fixed asset workflow relies on business rules. Rules repeat from one phase to another when the end user can make a change to a field affected by a business rule during that phase. Metaphase: Draft The fixed asset is in draft phases, prior to reconciliation. Phase Transition Description Not reconciled Manual The starting point for fixed asset, when the contract is drawn up. The result of the phase is the successful creation of a contract. When the fixed asset is reconciled, or partially reconciled, the Financial Manager can manually transition the fixed asset to the relevant active phase. Next phase: Partially reconciled or Reconciled Metaphase: Active The fixed asset is effective and in execution stages. Phase Transition Description Partially reconciled Manual The fixed asset is still being reconciled. When it's reconciled, the Financial Manager manually transitions the fixed asset to t

title: Expense Lines
content: Expense lines enable you to: Track and manage costs associated with contracts, devices, infrastructure & peripheral assets, licenses, subscriptions, and users. Optimize spend and resources by providing transparency into costs and budgets. Forecast expenses over a period to manage current budget and plan future budgets. Expense lines can be generated automatically based on cost allocation rules or created manually. Important: In order for the Expense Lines menu items to be displayed in Financial Management, the tenant admin must first enable the Enable expense line option in Administration > Configuration > Application Settings. Related topics To learn how to configure cost allocation rules, see Cost Allocation. To learn how to create expense lines manually, see Create an expense line manually. For more information about the Expense Lines page, see View an expense line.

title: Fiscal Years
content: Fiscal years enable you to specify a period of 12 months as a fiscal year for your company. Related topics Fiscal year workflow How to create a fiscal year record How to edit a fiscal year record

title: Fiscal year workflow
content: This section describes the metaphases and subordinate phases in the life cycle of a fiscal year record. All transitions between phases are manually triggered. Metaphase: Initial Phase Transition Description New Manual This is the starting point for the fiscal year. A fiscal year enters this phase after its creation. To make the fiscal year active, manually transition it to the Open phase. Next phase: Open Metaphase: Active Phase Transition Description Open Manual The fiscal year is available for selection. Next phase: Close Metaphase: Inactive (End) Phase Transition Description Close Manual The fiscal year isn't available for selection. Next phase: None Related topics How to create a fiscal year record How to edit a fiscal year record

title: Edit configuration option sets and options
content: The Configuration Options tab is read-only if the service design is published. To edit configuration option sets To edit a configuration option set: Select the service design version whose configuration options and option sets you want to modify. Select the Configuration Options tab. Select the option set you want to edit. Enter your changes in the right pane. Click Save. You can edit the following configuration option set options: Display Name — The display name for the option set or option. Description — A description for the option set or option. Image — An image that displays for the option set. Click Edit Image. Choose the image you want, and click Select. Click Upload Image to add your own image. Supported file extensions include .jpg, .jpeg, .gif, and .png. The recommended image size is 256 by 256 pixels, and the image will be scaled to the appropriate size. The image you select will be displayed in the Offerings area and in the Service Portal. Modify Options — Check the Modifia

title: Get started with OO Workflow Designer
content: Operations Orchestration (OO) Workflow Designer is a web-based environment for authoring flows, which is available as a standalone product that can be deployed either on a Windows or Linux server. It offers an intuitive drag-and-wire capability to design, create, share, and customize flows. The drag-and-wire visual interface enables rapid time-to-value. A visual flow debugger makes it easy to debug flows. OO Workflow Designer doesn’t require a connection to Central. All of its repository operations are available offline. If a source control interaction is required, you decide when the interaction occurs. In this manner, remote teams can use various standalone Workflow Designers, and it is even possible to author outside of the office network. Flows are authored in the CloudSlang language and run in OO Central. OO Workflow Designer has the following features: Web-based UI: OO Workflow Designer provides web access, which minimizes time-to-value and allows for simple management. Hybrid au

title: Edit the expression of a value for an input or output
content: ​The Expression Editor is a code console available as an optional editing option in OO Workflow Designer. You can use it to add or edit values of native OO and CloudSlang based Flows, Operations, Python Operations, and System Properties. Important: The Expression Editor supports Python 3.8.x and its earlier backward compatible versions to edit the values. You may note the following points related to Python 3.8.x support: By default, all the expressions created in the Expression Editor will be resolved as Python based expressions. All Python based operations created in OO Workflow Designer will be Python 3.8.x based. Jython based operations will continue to run as expected. Caution: If the Jython based operation has an expression defined on one of its inputs, outputs, or results, that expression might not be evaluated properly, if it's not Python 3.8.x supported. Jython based operations opened from the projects panel will continue to be editable. Jython based operations can no longer be

title: Extract and modify output values
content: You can extract and modify parts of an output, using python. For example, if you only want the maximum, minimum, and average round-trip times for a ping operation to a server, you can isolate and extract all three pieces of information from the operation’s raw output. Another example is to extract the HTTP code from an HTTP response. Extract and modify the output value In the Step Properties pane, under Outputs, or in the Flow Properties pane, under Outputs, select the output and click the Edit button. In the Expression Editor, enter the python expression to manipulate the output value. For example: To convert the output to lowercase, you just need to copy the following expression in the OO Workflow Designer UI: output1.lower() if the original expression was: pub1: ${output1.lower()} Click Save. Examples of using Python to manipulate outputs Diff Case Diff Case changes all the characters in the string either to upper case or to lower case. Example: # to change to lowercase output1.lowe

title: Hybrid authoring in OO Workflow Designer
content: As an author you can now open and use the native OO content packs steps along with CloudSlang content pack steps together to create flows or operations and vice-versa. The following actions can be performed in hybrid authoring: When you drag and drop the native step with configurations items set at flow level (system accounts, system property, and so on) the native configuration settings is lost requiring manual authoring and CloudSlang alignment. Open the native OO content packs flows, operation, system account, and system property. It must be noted that the linking of system account, system property, and configuration items such as selection lists, domain terms etc are disabled. View a proper reason for an invalid native OO items. Drag and drop the native OO items into CloudSlang flows. Link native OO step to CloudSlang step. Link flow variables into native OO steps such as inputs and outputs. Click Outputs and select to view and use the output field of the OO native content pack flo

title: Expression Language
content: The Expression Language is a language that enables you to construct meaningful expressions that you can enter in different parts of the user interface. The expressions can be of the following types: A logical expression A mathematical expression An object property A function call You can define complex expressions made up of combinations of these types of expressions. Note  Enclose the expressions within brackets {} and preceded by a $.  For example: ${entity.Owner.Id}.  You will see an error if you enter a wrong expression. Expression Language examples The following examples gives a brief preview of the scope of the Expression Language: ${entity.Name} returns the name of the current record. ${entity.Name == 'user1'} returns true if the name of the current record is user1; otherwise it returns false. ${entity.Owner.Name} returns the name of the owner of the current record. ${concat(entity.Name, entity.Owner.Name)} returns the name of the current record followed by the name of the owner
headings: Null values and collections in Expression Language
